jātakaaṭṭhakathā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a specific compound referring to the canonical commentary on the Jātaka collection in the Khuddaka Nikāya, attributed to Buddhaghosa.

jātikoṭisahassehi.meaning_2: with ten billion births; with ten billion rebirths
jātikoṭisahassehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound numeral jātikoṭisahassa, indicating 'with billions of births' in a cosmological or soteriological context, likely referring to the vast number of rebirths in saṃsāra.

pamāṇarahitaṃ.meaning_2: devoid of measure; without measurement; unmeasurable
pamāṇarahitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pamāṇa' (measure) is qualified by 'rahita' (devoid of), resulting in the sense of something lacking measurement, often used in philosophical contexts to describe qualities beyond empirical quantification.

cañjaliṃ.meaning_2: palms placed together (as a token of respect); hands cupped together (to drink water or hold some item)
cañjaliṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form cañjalin̐ is an accusative singular of añjali with sandhi (c + añjali > cañjali) and the anusvāra indicating nasalization typical in some Pāli texts or recitations. It likely appears in a context of offering respect or presenting something held in cupped hands.

patimānetvā.meaning_2: having honoured the master; having revered the lord
patimānetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form combines the preposition pati meaning 'against' or 'concerning' with the causal absolutive of √man 'to think', indicating an action of honouring directed towards or in relation to a master or lord. Without the specific sentence context, the interpretation leans towards 'having honoured the master' based on pati as a governing element.

sabbasammānabhājanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely meaning 'vessel for all kinds of honour' or 'complete sharing of respect'; the form suggests a neuter accusative singular, possibly indicating an object in context.

namassanādino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'namassana' (veneration) is qualified by 'ādino' (beginning with, etc.), commonly used to indicate a list starting with veneration and including similar acts.

pavattassānubhāvena.meaning_2: by the power of the arisen; by the majesty of what has occurred
pavattassānubhāvena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental-genitive sandhi compound where 'pavattassa' (gen sg of pavatta, 'of the arisen' or 'of what has proceeded') combines with 'ānubhāvena' (ins sg of ānubhāva, 'by power/majesty'). It likely expresses 'by the power arising from what has occurred' in a Buddhist context, possibly referring to the efficacy of arisen dhammas or events.

kāraṇamāgamma.meaning_2: due to the reason; on account of the cause; arriving by the cause
kāraṇamāgamma.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'kāraṇam' (acc. sg. nt. of kāraṇa 'cause') combines with 'āgamma' (gerund of āgacchati, indicating 'having come' or 'due to'), forming an indeclinable phrase expressing causality or relation, common in Pāḷi for 'by reason of' or 'in relation to the cause'.

apaṇṇakādīni.meaning_2: unquestionable etc.; indisputable and so on; guaranteed and the like
apaṇṇakādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form apaṇṇakādīni is the neuter plural of the compound apaṇṇakādi, used to refer to types of unquestionable truths or guaranteed matters and the like in Pāli texts, likely in a list or enumeration context.

lokanittharaṇatthiko.meaning_2: wanting the crossing over of the world; seeking the transcendence of the world
lokanittharaṇatthiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a descriptive compound adjective used to characterize someone desiring the transcendence or liberation from the cycle of worldly existence, common in Buddhist contexts referring to the aspiration for nirvana.

bodhisambhāre.meaning_2: requisite of enlightenment; necessary condition for awakening
bodhisambhāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bodhi' (enlightenment) qualifies 'sambhāra' (requisite), referring to the spiritual preparations or conditions essential for attaining bodhi. In Buddhist contexts, it often denotes the foundational elements or accumulations needed for enlightenment.

abhigantvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Absolutive form indicating prior action, commonly used in narrative contexts to describe sequence of events, e.g., 'having gone to the place...'.

asaṃsaṭṭhavihāre.meaning_2: dwellings aloof from; modes of living not associated with; residences detached from
asaṃsaṭṭhavihāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'asaṃsaṭṭha' (not mixed with, aloof from) qualifies 'vihāra' (dwelling, mode of living). The form 'asaṃsaṭṭhavihāre' is locative singular, indicating 'in aloof dwellings' or 'in modes of living detached from', likely referring to meditative states or lifestyles free from worldly entanglements in a Buddhist context.

suddhavihārinā.meaning_2: one living purely; one abiding in purity
suddhavihārinā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in a compound context to describe someone or something characterized by pure living or abiding; vihārī functions adjectivally, likely masculine by context in Pāḷi compounds.

buddhamittena.meaning_2: friend of the Buddha; follower of the Buddha
buddhamittena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound buddhamitta, used to indicate 'by/with the friend of the Buddha'. In Pāli texts, this often refers to a close associate or disciple of the Buddha.

mahiṃsāsakavaṃsamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely meaning 'the Mahiṃsa clan' or 'lineage of one's own buffalo', where mahiṃsa is buffalo, saka is one's own, and vaṃsa is lineage; used as a proper name for a family or group.

nayaññunā.meaning_2: one who knows the method; expert in inference; one versed in logic
nayaññunā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where naya refers to 'method' or 'inference' and ñū to 'knower'. It denotes a person knowledgeable in logical methods or philosophical reasoning, common in Buddhist texts discussing epistemology.

buddhadevena.meaning_2: Buddha; Awakened One as god; divine Buddha
buddhadevena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'buddha' (the Awakened One) is qualified by 'deva' (god), forming a respectful epithet often used in Pāli literature to denote the Buddha as a divine or supreme being. Without context, the primary sense is 'the Buddha who is a god'.

suddhabuddhinā.meaning_2: person with pure understanding; one whose intellect is purified
suddhabuddhinā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound suddhabuddhi, meaning a person with pure intelligence, formed from suddha 'pure' and buddhi 'intelligence' (opposite of abuddhi 'unintelligent person'). Used likely in a context describing someone of clear or purified mind.

mahāpurisacariyānaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of great men; behaviours of illustrious beings
mahāpurisacariyānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive plural form of a compound noun meaning 'the conduct of great men', often referring to exemplary behaviours in Buddhist texts.

vijjotayantassa.meaning_2: of the one who is shining; of the one who is flashing
vijjotayantassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the genitive singular masculine form of the present participle of vijjotati, indicating possession or relation to something shining or flashing, likely in a descriptive context such as a luminous or radiant entity.

jātakassatthavaṇṇanaṃ.meaning_2: explanation of the meaning of the Jātaka; commentary on the Jātaka
jātakassatthavaṇṇanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the accusative singular form, functioning as the object of a verb implying recitation or explanation. The genitive 'jātakassa' indicates possession, meaning 'of the Jātaka', while 'atthavaṇṇanā' specifies the explanation of the sense or meaning.

vācanāmagganissitaṃ.meaning_2: dependent on the path of recitation; based on the way of reading
vācanāmagganissitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something situated or relying on the path/method of recitation or reading aloud, likely in a textual or doctrinal context such as study of scriptures.

dūrenidānaṃ.meaning_2: from a distant cause; due to a remote origin
dūrenidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an adverbial accusative compound used in composition, indicating causation from a distant source. Without specific sentences, the interpretation is based on the components: 'dūre' (at a distance) + 'nidānaṃ' (due to the cause).

avidūrenidānaṃ.meaning_2: cause in the near vicinity; origin not far away
avidūrenidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'avidūrena' (instrumental singular of avidūra) modifies 'nidānaṃ' (accusative singular), used adverbially in composition to indicate 'due to a near cause' or 'because of proximity in origin'. The accusative form suggests adverbial usage in a sentence, common for nidānaṃ.

santikenidānanti.meaning_2: by the gift of peace thus; by the offering of pacification thus
santikenidānanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound or fused phrase resulting from 'santikena dānena iti', likely an adverbial expression in a vinaya or doctrinal context, meaning 'by the gift that brings peace, thus' or similar, where 'santikena' (instrumental of santika, 'peace-giving') modifies 'dānena' ('by the gift'). The fusion 'santikenidānanti' suggests scribal or metrical contraction.

vaṇṇiyamānā.meaning_2: being described; being delineated; being commented on
vaṇṇiyamānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vaṇṇiyamānā is the feminine nominative singular of the present participle of vaṇṇeti, indicating a female subject who is in the process of being praised or described. The root √vaṇṇ primarily connotes praising, with secondary senses of describing or commenting.

viññātattā.meaning_2: the state of being known; consciousness; cognized state
viññātattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form viññātattā is the ablative singular of the abstract noun viññātatta, derived by adding -tta to the past participle stem viññāt- of vijānāti. It denotes the condition or state of being known/cognized, often implying consciousness or awareness in philosophical contexts.

dīpaṅkarapādamūlasmiñhi.meaning_2: at the base of Dīpaṅkara's feet
dīpaṅkarapādamūlasmiñhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the compound noun, indicating location 'at the base of the feet of Dīpaṅkara' (the 24th previous Buddha). The particle 'hi' follows, adding emphasis or explanation to the context, likely in a narrative describing a scene of reverence or positioning.

vessantarattabhāvā.meaning_2: the state of being Vessantara; the incarnation as Vessantara
vessantarattabhāvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is feminine instrumental singular, likely referring to the state or incarnation of Vessantara in a narrative context, such as the Jātaka tale of the Buddha's previous birth.

tusitapure.meaning_2: Tusita city; city in the Tusita heaven
tusitapure.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word tusitapure is the locative singular form of the compound tusitapura, referring to the 'city in the Tusita heaven', a divine realm in Buddhist cosmology where the future Buddha resides.

sabbaññutappatti.meaning_2: attainment of omniscience; acquisition of infinite knowledge
sabbaññutappatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound formed from the abstract noun sabbaññutā (omniscience) and patti (attainment), indicating the process or achievement of becoming omniscient, often associated with the Buddha's enlightenment in Pāḷi texts.

santikenidānaṃ.meaning_2: introductory tale of pacification; origin of calming
santikenidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'santikānidāna', where 'santika' refers to pacifying (from santika 2.1) and 'nidāna' to introductory tale or origin (nidāna 4). The form 'santikānidānaṃ' suggests a neuter compound noun used adverbially or as an object, possibly meaning 'the story of pacification' in a narrative context like Vinaya introductions.

dūrenidānakathā.meaning_2: introduction from afar; distant origin story
dūrenidānakathā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where dūre (locative of dūra, 'far away') modifies nidānakathā ('introduction' or 'origin story'), likely indicating an introductory narrative set at a distance or from afar, common in Pāli texts for framing stories.

kappasatasahassādhikānaṃ.meaning_2: more than one hundred thousand aeons
kappasatasahassādhikānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where adhika modifies the numeral kappasatasahassa, indicating excess over 100,000 aeons. The form is genitive plural, likely referring to multiple such periods of time in a cosmological or temporal context.

amaravatī.meaning_2: Amaravatī; the abode of the immortals; heavenly city
amaravatī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Amaravatī is a proper name for a mythical city associated with gods or immortals in ancient Indian literature, derived from 'amara' (immortal) and 'vatī' (enclosure or abode).

brāhmaṇasippameva.meaning_2: just the skill of a Brahman; merely the craft of a priest
brāhmaṇasippameva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound 'brāhmaṇasippa' (Brahman's skill) in locative singular with emphatic 'eva' appended, functioning adverbially to mean 'just in the skill of a Brahman' or similar, likely in a context emphasizing exclusivity or limitation to priestly knowledge or craft.

āyapotthakaṃ.meaning_2: place of income; source of revenue
āyapotthakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A compound noun referring to a register or book concerning sources of income, commonly used in Vinaya contexts for monastic financial matters.

suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimuttādibharite.meaning_2: filled with gold, silver, jewels, pearls, etc.
suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimuttādibharite.construction: suvaṇṇarajat + a + maṇimuttā + ādi + bharit + e
suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimuttādibharite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an inflected form (instrumental singular neuter) of a complex tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adjective, describing something laden or filled with valuables beginning with gold and silver.

ayyakapayyakānanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound listing two related kinship terms, likely in a context enumerating family members or elders; the iti that follows indicates 'thus' or 'namely'.

sumedhapaṇḍito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by combining 'sumedha' (wise) and 'paṇḍita' (learned), inflected in the nominative singular to refer to a wise and knowledgeable person, likely in a descriptive or titular sense in the text.

pitupitāmahādayo.meaning_2: fathers, grandfathers, and so on; paternal ancestors and others
pitupitāmahādayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in nominative plural, used to denote a series starting with fathers and grandfathers, extending to other relatives or ancestors in a list-like context.

tāpasapabbajjaṃ.meaning_2: renunciation as an ascetic; going forth as a hermit
tāpasapabbajjaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'tāpasa' (ascetic, hermit) and 'pabbajjā' (renunciation, ordination). It likely refers to the act of renouncing worldly life to become an ascetic, distinct from formal Buddhist ordination.

panatthassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound of 'pana' (moreover; but) + 'atthassa' (genitive of 'attha', meaning), likely in the genitive case 'panatthassa' meaning 'of the matter' or 'of the case'. The form 'panatthassa' suggests contraction in a compound context, common in Pāli for connecting conjunction + noun.

āvibhāvatthaṃ.meaning_2: manifestation; purpose of appearance; state of becoming visible
āvibhāvatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where āvibhāva (manifestation) is the upapada for attha (purpose), indicating 'the purpose of manifestation' or 'state of manifestation'. The accusative form suggests it functions adverbially as 'for the sake of manifestation' in context.

sumedhakathā.meaning_2: discourse on good wisdom; talk about the wise
sumedhakathā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sumedha (wise, sage) qualifies kathā (discourse, talk), likely referring to a sermon or discussion concerning wisdom or a wise figure in Buddhist context.

gāthāsambandhena.meaning_2: connected with verses; in relation to verses
gāthāsambandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound gāthāsambandha, where gāthā (verse) is connected with sambandha (connection). In Buddhist contexts, often refers to textual material involving verses or poetic suttas.

sambandhadīpakehi.meaning_2: by those that illuminate connections; by those that explain relationships
sambandhadīpakehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound adjective/noun 'sambandhadīpaka', likely referring to explanatory elements or commentaries that clarify grammatical or conceptual connections in a text.

kappasatasahassādhikānañhi.meaning_2: indeed more than one hundred thousand aeons
kappasatasahassādhikānañhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound combining the numeral kappasatasahassa ('one hundred thousand aeons'), the adjective adhikāna ('more than', in neuter plural or locative case), and the particle hi ('indeed'). The form suggests a locative or instrumental plural construction, likely meaning 'indeed more than one hundred thousand aeons' in a context describing an extensive duration, such as in cosmology or soteriology.

amaravatīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a quotative adverbial phrase formed by combining the adjective 'amara' (deathless, unending) with 'vatī' (duteous, in the sense of 'as befits' or 'in the manner of'), followed by 'iti' (thus). It likely means 'thus as one who is deathless' or 'in the unending manner,' often used in Pāḷi to introduce a quoted statement or manner of action, especially in doctrinal contexts like describing the Buddha's eternal qualities.

annapānasamāyutanti.meaning_2: endowed with food and drink; provided with nourishment
annapānasamāyutanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'annapāna' (food and drink) is the object of 'samāyuta' (endowed with), forming an adjective describing something provided with sustenance. The 'nti' ending is an indeclinable quotative particle, often used to mark the end of a phrase or citation, but here it appears as part of the textual form, possibly indicating a quoted term in a grammatical or doctrinal context.

tāḷasaddena.meaning_2: sound of drumming; sound of percussion
tāḷasaddena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound tāḷasadda, denoting the sound produced by drumming or percussion instruments, likely in a musical or ritual context.

bherisaṅkharathāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a descriptive compound referring to locations characterized by intense noise or agitation, combining 'bheri' (drum), 'saṅkhara' (constructions or aggregates, here possibly noisy elements), and 'thāni' (places). The form appears to be neuter plural nominative or accusative.

sabbakammamupāgataṃ.meaning_2: reached all action; attained all intentional activity; entered into a state of complete action
sabbakammamupāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an accusative singular masculine or neuter past participle in a compound, likely modifying a masculine noun like 'buddham' in a Vinaya context, indicating one who has fully engaged in or attained all aspects of disciplinary actions or duties.

nānājanasamākulaṃ.meaning_1: filled with various people; crowded with different nationalities
nānājanasamākulaṃ.meaning_2: crowded with many diverse people; teeming with persons of various kinds
nānājanasamākulaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a Sanskrit compound used in a Pāli-like context, describing a place crowded with people of various origins. The neuter accusative singular form suggests it modifies a neuter noun like 'vihāraṃ' or similar in the implied sentence.

puññakamminaṃ.grammar: masc, agent in comps, from puñña + kamma
puññakamminaṃ.meaning_2: doer of meritorious deeds; performer of good actions
puññakamminaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive plural form used to indicate 'of those who perform meritorious deeds'; combines puñña (merit) with kammī (doer of action) as a descriptive compound.

amaravatiyā.meaning_2: of the abode of the immortals; of the heavenly city
amaravatiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a feminine noun denoting the mythical city Amaravatī, associated with gods or immortals in Indian mythology. The form is locative singular, indicating 'in/at the city of the immortals'. 'Vati' here functions as a suffix meaning 'abode' or 'enclosure', derived from √var, distinct from the unrelated 'vati' meaning fence.

anekakoṭisannicayo.meaning_2: accumulation of countless millions; vast stockpile
anekakoṭisannicayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'aneka' (countless) modifies 'koṭi' (ten million), and the whole quantifies 'sannicaya' (accumulation), indicating an immense quantity often used hyperbolically in texts to describe vast numbers.

pahūtadhanadhaññavā.meaning_2: very wealthy and fortunate; extremely rich and lucky
pahūtadhanadhaññavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ends in -ā, suggesting a feminine nominative singular or possibly vocative. It is a sandhi compound combining 'pahūtadhana' (very wealthy) and 'dhaññavā' (fortunate), likely from the stem 'dhaññavant' with feminine ending. Used to describe someone who is both materially rich and blessed with good fortune.

uparipāsādavaratale.meaning_2: on the excellent upper storey of the mansion; on the top terrace of the princely palace
uparipāsādavaratale.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'tala' (flat surface, level, storey) is qualified by 'uparipāsāda' (upper storey) and 'vara' (excellent, princely), likely functioning as a locative form in context, indicating position on the top excellent level of the palace or mansion.

paṭisandhiggahaṇaṃ.meaning_2: taking of the rebirth-linking; grasping of the connection to the next existence
paṭisandhiggahaṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where paṭisandhi (feminine abstract noun meaning rebirth-linking) is combined with gahaṇa (neuter action noun from √gah meaning taking or grasping). The entire form is neuter nominative/accusative singular, likely functioning as the object in the sentence.

nibbattanibbattaṭṭhāne.meaning_2: place of rebirth; state of arising; situation of birth
nibbattanibbattaṭṭhāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the compound 'nibbattaṭṭhāna', meaning 'in the place/state of rebirth or arising'. It combines 'nibbatta' (produced, reborn) with 'ṭhāna' (place, state), commonly used in Buddhist contexts to refer to the realm or condition of rebirth.

sarīrabhedanaṃ.meaning_2: breaking of the body; injuring the body
sarīrabhedanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sarīra' (body) serves as the object of 'bhedana' (breaking). In Pāḷi texts, such terms often appear in contexts of physical harm or dissection, possibly in Vinaya rules concerning injury to monks.

cintesahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi form where final -i of aorist cintesi merges with initial a- of pronoun ahaṃ, resulting in -e- as the linking vowel; represents the 1st person singular aorist 'I thought (about)' in narrative context.

yaṃnūnimaṃ.meaning_2: why not; what if; why shouldn't
yaṃnūnimaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form of 'kiṃ nūna iman' or similar, used as an interrogative adverb suggesting a proposal or rhetorical question. Without the sentence context, the exact usage is inferred from common Pāḷi constructions.

nānākuṇapapūritaṃ.meaning_2: filled with various corpses; filled with a variety of disgusting things
nānākuṇapapūritaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pūrita' functions nominally as the head, modified by 'nānākuṇapa'; the accusative singular form suggests it is the object in the sentence, describing something filled with diverse foul or cadaverous elements, likely in a metaphorical sense of impurity or defilement.

hetuye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] 'Hetu' is a common Pāḷi term in Buddhist contexts referring to the causal conditions underlying phenomena, often listed in the twelve nidānas of dependent origination.

paṭipakkhabhūtaṃ.meaning_2: that which has become opposed; opposing entity; contrary being
paṭipakkhabhūtaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the accusative singular neuter of the compound adjective paṭipakkhabhūta, used adverbially to indicate something that has become or is in an opposed state, often in contexts of conflict or opposition in Buddhist texts.

vūpasamabhūtaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound past participle functioning as an adjective or adverb, indicating a state of having subsided or become calm, likely describing a condition of peace or appeasement in context.

rāgādīnaṃ.meaning_2: passions etc.; desires and the like
rāgādīnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the genitive plural form of the compound 'rāgādi', meaning 'beginning with rāga' (passion, attachment), used to denote a class of afflictions or defilements in Buddhist contexts, such as the three poisons (rāga, dosa, moha).

paṭipakkhabhūto.meaning_2: become opposed; having become an opponent
paṭipakkhabhūto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound past participle where paṭipakkha (opponent) is the base, intensified by bhūta (become), indicating a state of having become opposed or antagonistic. Used adjectivally to describe something that has taken an opposing stance.

anavajjadhammopi.meaning_2: even one of irreproachable character; even faultless in nature
anavajjadhammopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a sandhi combination where 'anavajja-dhamma' (irreproachable nature) is adverbialized by 'api' (even), likely used to modify a verb or clause in context, emphasizing blameless quality despite circumstances.

sabbajātikkhepanato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an ablative form of a compound noun 'sabbajātikkhepanam', meaning 'from the throwing away of all births', i.e., 'from the rejection or denial of all rebirths'. Likely used in a Buddhist context to denote liberation or the state free from rebirth.

ajātisaṅkhātena.meaning_2: by the unproduced and reckoned; by that which is not born and designated
ajātisaṅkhātena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound ajātisaṅkhāta, used to describe something unproduced (ajāti) and yet conventionally designated or reckoned (saṅkhāta) in Buddhist philosophical contexts, likely referring to nirvana or ultimate reality.

bhavitabbamevāti.meaning_2: it must be so; it should indeed be thus
bhavitabbamevāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This form appears to be a fused adverbial expression where 'bhavitabba' (potential ptp, 'should be' or 'must be') is combined with 'eva' ('indeed') and 'iti' ('thus'), likely functioning as a quotative or emphatic clause marker in Pāḷi texts, emphasizing inevitability or necessity in context.

ajātipicchitabbakanti.meaning_2: that it should be desired as non-birth; that no-rebirth is to be wished for
ajātipicchitabbakanti.construction: a jāti + iccha itabba ka + iti
ajātipicchitabbakanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a quotative adverbial form (iti) enclosing the compound ajātipicchitabbakam, indicating 'that [this] is to be desired.' The compound ajāti ('non-birth') modifies picchitabbaka ('to be desired'), expressing a doctrinal notion in Buddhist texts where freedom from rebirth is something to be aspired to.

gūtharāsimhi.meaning_2: heap of dung; pile of excrement
gūtharāsimhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'heap of dung'. The locative singular form gūtharāsimhi indicates 'in the heap of dung'. The particle hi likely means 'indeed' or 'because' depending on context, but the word itself is the compound.

pañcavaṇṇapadumasañchannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective in accusative singular neuter, likely modifying a noun such as a surface or area in a poetic or architectural context, evoking imagery of lotus-covered splendor.

mahātaḷākaṃ.meaning_2: great lake; large pond; vast pool
mahātaḷākaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound adjective-noun construction, likely used to describe a prominent or large body of water in the context of the text.

agavesanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word agavesanaṃ is a compound formed by prefixing 'a-' (negation) to 'gavesana', indicating the opposite of searching or seeking. Without contextual sentences, the interpretation is based on standard derivation.

kilesamaladhovane.meaning_1: washing away of defilements and impurities
kilesamaladhovane.meaning_2: cleansing of mental stains; purification from defilements
kilesamaladhovane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the locative case, likely indicating 'in the washing of defilements and impurities' or 'by the cleansing of stains', commonly used in Buddhist contexts for spiritual purification.

amatamahānibbānataḷāke.meaning_2: in the lake of the great deathless Nibbāna
amatamahānibbānataḷāke.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where taḷāka (lake) is qualified by amatamahānibbāna (the great deathless Nibbāna); the form is locative singular, indicating position or context, likely metaphorical for immersion in the state of Nibbāna.

amatanibbānamahātaḷākassa.meaning_2: of the great lake of deathless Nibbāna
amatanibbānamahātaḷākassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of a descriptive compound where amatanibbāna modifies mahātaḷāka, likely metaphorical for the vast expanse of Nibbāna.

palāyanamagge.meaning_2: path of fleeing; way of escape
palāyanamagge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where palāyana (fleeing) qualifies magga (path), indicating the route or means of escape. The form palāyanamagge is locative singular, suggesting 'on the path of fleeing' or 'in the way of escape' in context.

byādhipīḷito.meaning_2: tormented by sickness; afflicted with disease
byādhipīḷito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a past passive participle compound where 'byādhi' (disease) serves as the agent of the torment described by 'pīḷita'. In Pāḷi texts, such forms often depict physical or mental suffering due to illness.

byādhitikicchake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The provided word 'byādhitikicchake' appears to be a sandhi form of the compound 'byādhi-tikicchake', likely in locative singular, meaning 'in the physician of disease' or 'in the doctor for illness'. The analysis focuses on the first component 'byādhi' as per the task structure; 'tikicchake' is the locative of 'tikicchaka' (doctor).

tikicchāpeti.grammar: pr, denom caus of tikicchā + eti
tikicchāpeti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tikicchāpeti is a denominative causative derived from the abstract noun tikicchā (medicine; healing), functioning as a present tense verb meaning 'heals' or 'cures', equivalent to the desiderative tikicchati but with causative nuance via the eti ending.

kilesabyādhipīḷito.meaning_1: tormented by the disease of defilements
kilesabyādhipīḷito.meaning_2: oppressed by the sickness of unwholesome mental states; harassed by impurities
kilesabyādhipīḷito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex sandhi compound where the nominal compound 'kilesabyādhi' (disease of defilements) serves as the object of the past participle 'pīḷita' (tormented by), inflected in instrumental singular to indicate the agent of torment. The form reflects the ablaut and sandhi rules typical in such bahuvrīhi-like constructions in Pāli.

kilesavūpasamamaggakovidaṃ.meaning_1: skilled in the path of settling defilements; expert in the way to calming unwholesome mental states
kilesavūpasamamaggakovidaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound adjective describing a person (likely the Buddha) who is an expert in the path that leads to the calming of defilements, a common epithet in Pāli texts.

kilesavināsakassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of the compound adjective, likely describing the Buddha or a similar figure as one who destroys defilements in a Buddhist context.

kilesamaladhove.meaning_1: in the washing away of the stain of defilements
kilesamaladhove.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a locative tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adverbial phrase, with kilesamala (nt) in locative singular kilesamaladhove and dhoveti (present indicative 3sg, causative of dhovati) integrated into the compound structure, likely for the purpose of expressing 'in the act of washing away the defilement-stain'.

pariruddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Past participle indicating a state of being completely enclosed or surrounded, often used in contexts of restriction or imprisonment.

gamanampathe.meaning_2: wrong way of going; deviation in journeying
gamanampathe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'gamanampathe' likely appears in locative singular case, indicating 'on the wrong path of going' or 'in the deviation of journeying', combining the neuter noun 'gamana' (going, journey) with 'apathā' (wrong way).

kilesapariruddho.meaning_2: obstructed by defilements; blocked by kilesas
kilesapariruddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a past participle compound used adjectivally, likely describing a state of being obstructed by mental defilements (kilesas) in a Buddhist context, such as in the path to enlightenment.

sivamañjase.meaning_2: auspicious ointment; blessed collyrium; auspicious anointment
sivamañjase.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sivamañjase is the locative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound sivamañjasa, combining 'siva' (auspicious, blessed) with 'añjasa' (straight path, possibly metaphorically extended to 'straight application' or 'direct anointment' in a ritual sense). The locative case suggests 'in the auspicious ointment' or 'by means of the blessed anointment', likely referring to a purifying or ritual substance in a religious context, such as an epithet or tool associated with auspiciousness or Nibbāna.

nibbānanagaraṃ.meaning_2: city of nibbāna; town of emancipation; fortress of quenching
nibbānanagaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where nibbāna, the state of ultimate liberation, is metaphorically portrayed as a 'city' or 'fortress' of peace and security, common in Pāḷi literature to evoke an ideal refuge from saṃsāra.

naranāriyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A dvanda compound formed from 'nara' (man) and 'nārī' (woman), likely in the vocative singular form as used in direct address or enumeration in Pāli texts.

dasantena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word 'dasantena' appears to be an instrumental singular form of the feminine noun 'dasā', meaning 'with a fringe' or 'by the edge'. Without the full sentence context, the precise usage cannot be determined, but it likely refers to something bordered or edged in a descriptive or locative sense.

nānāratanāni.meaning_2: various jewels; different gems; diverse treasures
nānāratanāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative plural form of a bahuvrīhi or determinative compound, used to denote a collection of jewels of various kinds. The primary sense draws from ratana as 'jewel; gem; treasure' modified by nānā 'various; different'.

ratananāsabhayena.meaning_2: without fear of the destruction of the jewels; fearless regarding the loss of treasures
ratananāsabhayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound where 'ratana' (jewel, treasure) is qualified by 'nāsabhaya' (fear of destruction). The overall sense is fearlessness concerning the ruin or loss of precious things, likely in a Buddhist context symbolizing detachment from material wealth.

ratanavilopakacorasadiso.meaning_2: like a thief who plunders jewels; resembling a robber of treasures
ratanavilopakacorasadiso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adjective, likely modifying a masculine noun in context, portraying someone as comparable to a thief who destroys or steals jewels/treasures.

ariyamaggakusaladhammaratanaṃ.meaning_2: treasure of the wholesome dhammas of the noble path
ariyamaggakusaladhammaratanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in accusative singular, likely referring to the 'jewel' or 'treasure' consisting of the wholesome qualities (kusaladhammā) associated with the noble eightfold path (ariyamagga) in Buddhist contexts.

corasadisaṃ.meaning_2: like a thief; resembling a robber
corasadisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'cora' (thief) is qualified by 'sadisa' (similar to), functioning as an adjective describing something thief-like. No contextual sentences provided, so meaning is general.

mocayitvāna.meaning_2: having freed; having released; having saved
mocayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Absolutive form indicating prior action, commonly used in narratives to denote 'after having done something'. The prefix 'mo-' is a variant of 'muñc-' in causative contexts.

tathevimaṃ.meaning_2: thus; in this way; just so
tathevimaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'tathevimaṃ' appears to be a scribal error or variant of 'tathevaṃ', a common adverbial phrase in Pāḷi meaning 'thus' or 'in this manner', often used to introduce explanations or continuations. Without context sentences, the precise usage is inferred from standard occurrences in texts like the suttas.

nānākuṇapasañcayaṃ.meaning_2: accumulation of various corpses; collection of diverse disgusting things
nānākuṇapasañcayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sañcaya (accumulation) is qualified by nānākuṇapa (various corpses), likely used in a context of revulsion or impermanence, such as in Buddhist texts describing foulness meditation.

uccāraṭṭhānamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where uccāra (excrement) specifies the type of ṭhāna (place), indicating a designated location for bodily waste, common in monastic rules of the Vinaya.

udagāhiniṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a compound noun in the accusative singular feminine, likely referring to a stream or current flowing upwards, possibly in a metaphorical or literal sense within the text.

navacchiddaṃ.meaning_2: new and unbroken; fresh and flawless
navacchiddaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form navacchiddaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of a compound past participle, combining 'nava' (new) with 'avacchidda' (cut down, but here negated in sense to mean unbroken). It describes something new and without cracks or flaws, likely in a Vinaya context referring to a new monk who is flawless or without faults.

dhuvassavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound form of 'dhuva' (constant) and 'assava' (discharge, outflow), in accusative singular, likely referring to a persistent or unending flow in a doctrinal or metaphorical context, such as outflows of defilements in Buddhist texts.

jiṇṇanāvaṃva.meaning_2: like an old ship; as if a dilapidated boat
jiṇṇanāvaṃva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as a simile, comparing something to an aged or worn-out ship, evoking imagery of decay or obsolescence in the context.

bhaṇḍamādiya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound gerund where 'bhaṇḍa' (goods, merchandise) functions as the object of the verbal action 'ādiya' (taking up). It describes the act of taking or seizing goods, common in Vinaya contexts referring to lay-monastic interactions involving possessions.

bhaṇḍacchedabhayaṃ.meaning_2: fear of loss of goods; fear of severing possessions
bhaṇḍacchedabhayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bhaṇḍa' (goods) is qualified by 'cheda' (cutting, loss), forming 'bhaṇḍaccheda' (loss of goods), which then combines with 'bhaya' (fear) to denote fear arising from the potential loss of possessions. The accusative form suggests it functions as the object of fear in context.

mahācorasamo.meaning_2: equal to a master thief; like a criminal mastermind
mahācorasamo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adjective, likely describing someone who is comparable to or behaves like a master thief in context.

pahāyimaṃ.meaning_2: having left this; abandoning this; giving up this
pahāyimaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an adverbial phrase combining the gerund pahāya ('having left') with the accusative pronoun imaṃ ('this'), functioning as a postpositional phrase meaning 'having left this behind'. The form pahāyimaṃ suggests a fused or sandhi-like construction common in Pāli texts for such adverbial expressions, indicating the object of abandonment.

kusalacchedanābhayāti.meaning_2: freedom from the fear of cutting off wholesomeness; lack of fear regarding the severing of good deeds
kusalacchedanābhayāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound forming an adverbial phrase with 'iti', likely expressing a state of fearlessness about the potential loss or interruption of wholesome actions or merits, common in Buddhist contexts discussing ethical conduct or meditation.

nekkhammūpasaṃhitaṃ.meaning_2: associated with renunciation; bound up with going forth
nekkhammūpasaṃhitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an accusative singular neuter form of a compound adjective used nominally, likely in a Vinaya or doctrinal context referring to something connected with renunciation (e.g., a text or practice). The form suggests a bahuvrīhi or karmadhāraya compound.

sakanivesane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'saka' (one's own) with 'nivesana' (house, home). The -e ending indicates locative singular, denoting 'in one's own home'. The dictionary provides separate entries for both components, supporting this analysis.

kapaṇaddhikādīnaṃ.meaning_2: of tramps, travellers, and so on
kapaṇaddhikādīnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive plural form of the compound kapaṇaddhikādi, used to indicate possession or relation to a class including tramps, travellers, etc., and similar categories.

amaranagarato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the ablative singular of the compound amaranagara, combining 'amara' (immortal, endless) and 'nagara' (city), likely referring to a mythical or divine city in context.

nīvaraṇadosehi.meaning_2: by faults of hindrance; by defilements of obstruction
nīvaraṇadosehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound nīvaraṇadosa, where nīvaraṇa denotes mental hindrances (as in Buddhist contexts) and dosa refers to faults or corruptions, likely indicating obstructive defilements that block spiritual progress.

cittetiādinā.meaning_2: by one beginning with Citta; by the one starting with Citta
cittetiādinā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of a tatpuruṣa compound formed from the proper name 'Citteti' (likely a variant or error for 'Citta', a common lay disciple name) and 'ādi' meaning 'beginning with, etc.', indicating a list or group starting with this person. The form suggests a contextual usage in enumerating individuals or examples.

kāraṇaguṇehi.meaning_2: by qualities of the cause; by characteristics of the reason
kāraṇaguṇehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound kāraṇaguṇa, likely referring to the qualities or attributes associated with a cause or reason in philosophical or doctrinal context.

abhiññāsaṅkhātaṃ.meaning_2: that which is known by direct knowledge; that which is reckoned with higher understanding
abhiññāsaṅkhātaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'saṅkhātaṃ' (reckoned, designated) is qualified by 'abhiññā' (direct knowledge), forming a past participle agreeing with a neuter accusative singular noun. It likely refers to something conceptualized or named through supernormal insight in a doctrinal context.

navadosasamannāgataṃ.meaning_2: not endowed with new faults; free from fresh defects
navadosasamannāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the accusative singular masculine/neuter of the compound adjective, likely modifying a masculine noun in context. 'Nava' indicates freshness of the 'dosa' (faults), and 'samannāgata' with the negative prefix 'na-' (implied in lemma_1 as 'nava' but structurally na- before the verbal part) means not possessing such faults.

dvādasaguṇasamannāgataṃ.grammar: nt, comp, pp of saṃ anu ā √gam
dvādasaguṇasamannāgataṃ.meaning_2: endowed with twelve qualities; possessing twelvefold attributes
dvādasaguṇasamannāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something neuter nominative/accusative singular that has arrived together with twelve qualities, likely referring to a concept or object possessing twelve virtuous attributes in a doctrinal context.

aṭṭhadosasamākiṇṇaṃ.meaning_2: filled with eight faults; beset with eight defects
aṭṭhadosasamākiṇṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound adjective describes something pervaded or filled with the eight faults (likely the eight worldly dhammas or specific vices in Buddhist context), used in accusative singular masculine or neuter to modify a preceding noun.

dasaguṇasamannāgataṃ.meaning_2: endowed with ten qualities; possessing ten virtues
dasaguṇasamannāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective describing something or someone possessing ten specific qualities or virtues, common in Pāḷi texts for listing attributes like the ten perfections (dasa pāramiyo) or similar enumerations.

dhaññavikatiṃ.meaning_2: change in fortune; alteration of auspiciousness
dhaññavikatiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be an accusative singular form of a compound dhaññavikati, combining 'dhañña' (auspicious, fortunate) with 'vikati' (change, transformation), likely indicating a shift or alteration in one's fortunate state. Without the specific sentences provided, the interpretation is based on the dictionary entries and standard Pāḷi compounding.

nisajjaṭṭhānacaṅkamanavaseneva.meaning_2: by means of (only) the sitting place and the walking (meditation path)
nisajjaṭṭhānacaṅkamanavaseneva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular adverbial compound formed from nisajjaṭṭhāna (nt, 'sitting place'), caṅkamana (nt, 'walking meditation path'), and vasena (instr of vasa, 'by means of') with emphatic eva ('only'). It indicates exclusivity to these two monastic facilities, likely in a Vinaya context restricting other uses or possessions.

sattāhabbhantareyeva.meaning_2: within a week; in seven days only
sattāhabbhantareyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi compound indicating a short time frame, 'within a week only', emphasizing immediacy in the context of the sentence.

yathāpatthitaṃ.meaning_2: as desired; according to what was wished for
yathāpatthitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adverbial phrase used in the accusative neuter singular, likely modifying an action or object in the sentence to indicate it occurs in the manner that was desired or sought after.

abhiññābalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'abhiññā' (psychic power or direct knowledge) as the upapada with 'bala' (strength), resulting in a neuter noun denoting the power or ability associated with supernormal knowledge. The form is accusative singular, likely functioning as the object in the original sentence.

nekakoṭisataṃ.meaning_2: innumerable billions; countless hundreds of millions
nekakoṭisataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral indicating an extremely large, essentially innumerable quantity, formed by 'neka' (many, not one) modifying 'koṭisata' (one billion). In Buddhist texts, such numbers often denote vast cosmological scales or hyperbole for abundance.

himavantamupāgamiṃ.construction: himavant + am upā + gam + i + ṃ
himavantamupāgamiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form where 'himavantam' (accusative singular of himavant, 'Himalayas') is combined with 'upāgamiṃ' (first person singular aorist of upāgacchati, 'I approached'). The sandhi likely resolves the final -m of himavantam with the initial u- of upāgamiṃ across a word boundary in verse or text. The meaning indicates the speaker's approach to the Himalayan mountains, common in epic or narrative contexts like the Rāmāyaṇa.

himavantassāvidūre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form himavantassāvidūre results from sandhi in the genitive singular of himavant (Himalayas) combined with the adverb avidūre (near to), with 'assa' (gen. sg. ending) contracting to 'ā' before the initial 'a' of avidūre, yielding sāvidūre; the entire expression functions adverbially to indicate proximity to the Himalayan mountains.

pañcadosavivajjitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'avoided from the five faults,' where vivajjitaṃ is the past participle of vivajjeti (to avoid, turn away from), and dosa here refers to faults or defects. The form is neuter nominative/accusative singular, likely describing a state or object free from the five dosas (possibly the five hindrances or similar in Buddhist context).

aṭṭhaguṇasamupetaṃ.meaning_2: endowed with eight good qualities; possessing eight positive characteristics
aṭṭhaguṇasamupetaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective formed by combining 'aṭṭhaguṇa' (eight qualities) with the past participle 'samupeta' (endowed with), inflected in neuter accusative singular to modify a neuter noun, describing something possessed of the eight positive attributes often associated with noble qualities in Pāḷi texts.

abhiññābalamāhariṃ.meaning_2: I brought the power of direct knowledge; I fetched the supernormal ability
abhiññābalamāhariṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where abhiññābalam (nt, 'power of direct knowledge') is the object of the aorist verb āhariṃ ('I brought'). The sandhi occurs at the junction of balaṃ and āhariṃ, with m + ā > mā. In context, it likely describes bringing forth or manifesting psychic power through realization.

navadosamupāgataṃ.meaning_2: arrived with new ill-will; approached with fresh aversion
navadosamupāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something or someone that has approached or entered a state accompanied by newly arisen ill-will or hatred. 'Nava' indicates freshness or recentness, 'dosa' refers to aversion or malice, and 'samupāgataṃ' is the past participle indicating arrival or attainment. The accusative singular neuter form suggests it may modify a neuter noun in the original sentence, such as a state or condition.

dvādasaguṇamupāgataṃ.meaning_2: having reached twelvefold; attained twelve times
dvādasaguṇamupāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound dvādasaguṇa means 'twelvefold' or 'twelve times', with dvādasa as cardinal number and guṇa in its multiplicative sense; the past participle indicates a completed action of reaching this state.

dasahupāgataṃ.meaning_2: arrived within ten days; come in a period of ten days
dasahupāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular neuter, likely functioning adverbially or as an object describing an event or state reached within ten days, based on the participial element.

anekaguṇasampannaṃ.meaning_2: endowed with many qualities; possessing numerous virtues
anekaguṇasampannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular masculine/neuter form of the compound adjective, likely describing a person endowed with countless virtues or excellences, as in a laudatory context.

pavattaphalamādiyiṃ.meaning_2: result of action; consequence of what has occurred
pavattaphalamādiyiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where pavatta (past participle 'occurred' or 'happened') modifies phala ('fruit' or 'result'), indicating the outcome or fruition of an event or action. Common in doctrinal contexts for karmic results.

tatthappadhānaṃ.meaning_2: effort therein; striving in that regard
tatthappadhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where tattha specifies the location or regard of the padhāna (effort/striving). The accusative case suggests an object of action or reference in the sentence context.

nisajjaṭṭhānacaṅkame.meaning_2: place for sitting and walking meditation
nisajjaṭṭhānacaṅkame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'nisajjaṭṭhāna' (sitting place) and 'caṅkama' (walking meditation path), referring to a monastic area designated for both sitting and walking meditation practices.

abhiññābalapāpuṇinti.meaning_2: thus having attained the strength of direct knowledge; thus having realized the power of higher understanding
abhiññābalapāpuṇinti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as an adverbial phrase, likely in a doctrinal context describing attainment of supernormal powers through realization. The aorist pāpuṇi indicates completed action, and iti quotatively frames the statement.

sumedhapaṇḍitena.meaning_2: by the wise sage; by the learned intelligent man
sumedhapaṇḍitena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound sumedhapaṇḍita, combining sumedha 'wise man, sage' and paṇḍita 'learned, wise'; used in context to denote a wise or learned person in an action or agency role.

assamapaṇṇasālācaṅkamā.meaning_2: walking meditation path in a monastery or monk's dwelling
assamapaṇṇasālācaṅkamā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound where 'assama' (monastery) and 'paṇṇasālā' (monk's dwelling) describe the location of the 'caṅkama' (walking meditation path), forming a descriptive genitive compound indicating a path for meditation within such a setting.

vissakammadevaputtaṃ.meaning_2: son of Visvakarman; architect of the gods
vissakammadevaputtaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Accusative singular form of the compound proper name referring to the divine architect's son or a minor deity associated with Visvakarman, the celestial builder in Buddhist cosmology.

dhammikapabbate.meaning_2: the lawful mountain; the righteous mountain; the mountain according to the Dhamma
dhammikapabbate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in locative singular case, likely referring to a mountain characterized by or named after dhammika qualities, such as a place associated with lawful or righteous teachings in Buddhist context.

pañcadosavivajjitanti.meaning_2: free from the five faults; free from the five defects
pañcadosavivajjitanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an adjective in nominative plural, likely modifying a masculine or neuter noun in context, describing something free from the five dosas (faults or hindrances). The -ti ending is an adverbial particle 'thus' appended for emphasis.

paṇṇacchadanasālāpi.meaning_2: hall with a leaf covering; pavilion with foliage roof
paṇṇacchadanasālāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound noun describing a structure (likely a temporary or open pavilion) covered with leaves or foliage, common in ancient Indian architecture for shade or shelter; api adds emphasis or concessive nuance ('even the...'), but the core meaning is the leaf-covered hall.

caṅkamadosā.meaning_2: aversion during walking meditation; ill-will while walking
caṅkamadosā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound caṅkamadosā combines caṅkama (walking meditation) and dosā (instrumental singular of dosa, aversion). It likely refers to aversion or ill-will arising in the context of walking meditation, a common topic in Buddhist texts on mental hindrances.

thaddhavisamabhūmibhāgasmiñhi.meaning_2: plot of land that is hard and uneven
thaddhavisamabhūmibhāgasmiñhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound describing a specific type of terrain; thaddha indicates firmness or hardness of the ground, visama suggests uneven or rough nature, making the plot perilous or unsuitable for certain activities like meditation or travel.

mudusamatale.meaning_2: soft flat surface; level ground that is soft or pliable
mudusamatale.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'mudu' (soft, pliable) with 'samatala' (flat surface, level ground), likely describing a terrain or surface that is both soft and even, possibly metaphorical for a mild or accommodating situation.

thaddhavisamabhūmibhāgatā.meaning_2: fact of being land that is rough and firm; state of having terrain that is uneven and stiff
thaddhavisamabhūmibhāgatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an abstract feminine noun formed as a tatpuruṣa compound, where 'thaddha' (firm, stiff) and 'visama' (rough, uneven) qualify 'bhūmibhāga' (piece of land), with '-tā' indicating the abstract state. Likely used to describe challenging or unyielding terrain in a metaphorical or literal sense.

tiṇalatādigahanacchanne.grammar: sandhi, nt + fem + masc + nt + pp
tiṇalatādigahanacchanne.meaning_2: covered by a thicket beginning with grass and creepers
tiṇalatādigahanacchanne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound in the locative singular neuter, modifying an implied or preceding noun, indicating something covered or concealed by a dense growth starting with grass, creepers, etc. The final nacchanne is a past participle form meaning 'covered' in a negative sense, but contextually adapted to 'covered by' in the thicket imagery typical of Pāli descriptions of wilderness or seclusion.

andhakāravelāyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'time of darkness', used in locative singular to indicate 'at the time of darkness', likely referring to night or a period of obscurity.

uragādike.meaning_2: snake and so forth; beginning with snakes
uragādike.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi-like compound used in lists, indicating 'snakes and the like' or categories starting with snakes, common in Pāḷi enumerations of creatures or examples.

diyaḍḍharatanaṃ.meaning_2: one and a half jewels; one and a half treasures
diyaḍḍharatanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form diyaḍḍharatanaṃ is the accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'one and a half jewels' or 'a jewel and a half'. Likely used in a context enumerating items, such as offerings or possessions.

ratanamattaanucaṅkamaṃ.meaning_2: space on the side of a walking path, as many as the jewels; sidewalk of the length of the jewels
ratanamattaanucaṅkamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound indicating a side-walk or path space equivalent in measure to jewels, likely in a context of opulent or measured architectural description. The form is accusative singular, suggesting use as an object in a sentence.

samavippakiṇṇavālukaṃ.meaning_2: level ground strewn with sand; even terrain covered in scattered sand
samavippakiṇṇavālukaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (karmadhāraya) where 'sama' modifies 'vippakiṇṇavālukaṃ', indicating sand that is scattered about on level ground. The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the direct object in the sentence, likely describing a location or surface.

dīpappasādakamahindattherassa.meaning_2: of the Elder Mahinda, Illuminator of the Island
dīpappasādakamahindattherassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex genitive compound likely referring to the Elder Mahinda who dispelled doubt in Sri Lanka (dīpa as island), a historical figure in Pāli literature associated with the spread of Buddhism. The compound functions as a proper name in genitive case.

aṭṭhaguṇasamupetanti.meaning_2: endowed with eight good qualities; possessing eight positive characteristics
aṭṭhaguṇasamupetanti.construction: aṭṭha + guṇa + saṃ + upa + e + ta
aṭṭhaguṇasamupetanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound adjective describing someone or something characterized by the possession of eight virtues or positive attributes, common in Pāḷi texts to denote moral or spiritual excellence.

dhanadhaññapariggahābhāvo.meaning_2: absence of wealth and grain possessions; lack of material and agricultural resources
dhanadhaññapariggahābhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'dhanadhaññapariggaha' (possessions of wealth and grain) is qualified by 'abhāvo' (absence), indicating a state of lacking such resources, common in ascetic or monastic contexts.

anavajjapiṇḍapātapariyesanabhāvo.meaning_2: state of irreproachable searching for alms food; blameless condition of seeking alms
anavajjapiṇḍapātapariyesanabhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound describing a virtuous or faultless state in the monastic practice of seeking alms, likely in a Vinaya context emphasizing ethical conduct during alms rounds.

nibbutapiṇḍapātabhuñjanabhāvo.meaning_2: state of one who has attained nibbāna eating almsfood
nibbutapiṇḍapātabhuñjanabhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex dvanda-like compound in genitive case, describing the existential state (bhāva) of an enlightened being (nibbuta) who consumes (bhuñjana) almsfood (piṇḍapāta), often referring to the arahant's final existence before parinibbāna.

dhanasāraṃ.meaning_2: wealth of essence; essential wealth; treasure of value
dhanasāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'dhana' (wealth) and 'sāra' (essence), used in instrumental case singular. The accusative form suggests it functions as an object in the sentence, likely referring to something of substantial or intrinsic value.

sīsakahāpaṇādīni.meaning_1: beginning with head and silver coin; head, silver coin, etc.
sīsakahāpaṇādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sīsa' (head) and 'kahāpaṇa' (silver coin) are connected to 'ādi' (beginning with, etc.), indicating a list starting with these items, likely in a legal or enumerative context of the Vinaya.

raṭṭhapīḷanakilesābhāvo.meaning_2: absence of oppression and defilement in the country; lack of affliction and impurity in the realm
raṭṭhapīḷanakilesābhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'abhāvo' (absence) is the final member, qualified by the preceding elements 'raṭṭhapīḷanakilesa' meaning 'country-oppression-defilement'. It likely refers to an ideal state of a kingdom free from oppression and moral impurities.

nicchandarāgabhāvo.meaning_2: state of being without desire and attachment
nicchandarāgabhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'the state (bhāva) of absence of desire (nicchanda) and attachment (arāga)'. It denotes a mental condition free from passion and longing, commonly used in Buddhist contexts to describe dispassion or equanimity.

coravilope.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'cora' (thief) qualifies 'vilopa' (looting), indicating plundering carried out by thieves. The related entries suggest 'cora' from √cur (to steal) and 'vilopa' from vi + √lup (to cut off or seize), fitting the context of illicit seizure.

nibbhayabhāvo.meaning_2: state of fearlessness; condition of being unafraid
nibbhayabhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where nibbhaya (adj. 'fearless') qualifies bhāva (masc. 'state'), denoting the abstract state or quality of fearlessness. In Pāḷi literature, such terms often describe virtuous mental conditions.

rājarājamahāmattehi.meaning_2: with royal ministers; with the king's cabinet members
rājarājamahāmattehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'rāja' (king) and 'rājamahāmatta' (royal minister), indicating association with the king's ministers. The repetition of 'rāja' suggests emphasis on royal status, common in administrative contexts.

asaṃsaṭṭhabhāvo.meaning_2: state of being not mixed-up; state of being aloof
asaṃsaṭṭhabhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where asaṃsaṭṭha (past participle meaning 'not sticking' or 'aloof') is qualified by bhāva ('state'). The compound denotes the abstract state or condition of being detached or not associated.

appaṭihatabhāvoti.meaning_2: state of being unobstructed; state of being unimpeded
appaṭihatabhāvoti.construction: na > a + pati + √han + ta > appaṭihata + √bhū > bhāv + *a
appaṭihatabhāvoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appaṭihatabhāvoti is a sandhi compound consisting of the abstract noun appaṭihata-bhāva 'state of being unobstructed' (from the past participle appaṭihata 'unobstructed' + bhāva 'state') followed by the quotative particle iti 'thus'. The sandhi involves the assimilation of t + bh > ṭṭh (appaṭihata + bhāva > appaṭihaṭṭhabhāva), but the provided text form suggests a variant or scribal rendering as appaṭihatabhāvoti, likely a technical term in grammatical or philosophical contexts denoting the condition of unobstructedness.

abhiññābalamāharinti.meaning_2: they brought the power of supernormal knowledge; they fetched the strength of higher understanding
abhiññābalamāharinti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as a quotative phrase in Pāli, where 'āharinti' (3rd pl. aor. of āharati + iti) introduces reported speech or thought, equivalent to 'they say' or 'it is said that'. The core is 'abhiññābalaṃ āharinti', meaning 'they brought the power of direct knowledge/supernormal ability', likely in a context of attaining or manifesting psychic powers through realization.

thāmappattaṃ.meaning_2: unattained strength; unaccomplished fortitude; not reached steadfastness
thāmappattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'appatta' (not attained) modifies 'thāma' (strength or steadfastness), resulting in the neuter accusative singular form. The word likely describes something that has not achieved or reached a state of fortitude or resilience, possibly in a doctrinal context referring to unaccomplished spiritual strength.

vipassanābalaṃ.meaning_2: strength of insight; power of introspection
vipassanābalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vipassanā (insight) qualifies bala (strength), referring to the mental power derived from penetrating vision in Buddhist practice.

vipassanābalassa.meaning_2: strength of insight; power of introspection
vipassanābalassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form vipassanābalassa indicates possession, as in 'of the strength of insight', commonly used in Buddhist texts to denote the mental power derived from vipassanā practice.

navadosamupāgatanti.meaning_2: arrived with new ill-will; having approached with fresh hatred
navadosamupāgatanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound used adverbially with 'iti', indicating 'having arrived with new dosa (ill-will)'. Likely from Vinaya context referring to a monk's fresh aversion.

kuṭileṇacaṅkamādipaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.meaning_2: adorned with a hut, cave, walking path, etc.
kuṭileṇacaṅkamādipaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex bahuvrīhi compound serving as a past participle in neuter accusative singular, describing something (likely a place or monastery) that is adorned or equipped with monastic dwellings like huts and caves, walking meditation paths, and so on.

pupphūpagaphalūpagarukkhasañchannaṃ.grammar: sandhi, adj + adj + adj + adj + masc + pp
pupphūpagaphalūpagarukkhasañchannaṃ.meaning_2: covered with trees that are approached by flowers and fruits
pupphūpagaphalūpagarukkhasañchannaṃ.family_compound: puppha upaga phala upaga rukkha sañchanna
pupphūpagaphalūpagarukkhasañchannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex tatpuruṣa compound serving as an adjective in accusative singular neuter or masculine. It describes something (likely a place or area) covered with trees where flowers and fruits approach or grow towards, evoking an image of a flourishing, tree-shaded grove. The repetition of 'upaga' links to trees approached by floral and fruity elements, possibly metaphorical for abundance.

madhurasalilāsayaṃ.meaning_2: abode of sweet water; place resting in lovely waters
madhurasalilāsayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound, likely referring to a body of water or reservoir characterized by its sweet (fresh) quality, with 'saya' indicating its resting or situated nature. The ending -aṃ suggests an adverbial or locative sense, but as a compound noun, it functions as a neuter indeclinable in certain contexts.

apagatavāḷamigabhiṃsanakasakuṇaṃ.meaning_2: free from frightening wild beasts and birds
apagatavāḷamigabhiṃsanakasakuṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an elaborate bahuvrīhi compound where apagata functions adjectivally as the first member, qualifying the rest of the compound (vāḷamiga-bhiṃsanaka-sakuṇa), denoting 'free from terrifying beasts and birds'. The form is accusative singular neuter, likely modifying an unstated noun such as bhayaṃ (fear) or a place.

pavivekakkhamaṃ.meaning_2: fit for solitude; suitable for seclusion; tolerant of seclusion
pavivekakkhamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pavivekakkhamaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the compound adjective pavivekakkhama, combining paviveka 'solitude, seclusion' with khama 'fit for, suitable for'. It likely functions adjectivally modifying a neuter noun in context, expressing suitability or tolerance for solitary practice.

alaṅkatacaṅkamassa.meaning_2: decorated walking path; adorned meditation walk
alaṅkatacaṅkamassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun referring to a walking path that is adorned or decorated, likely in a monastic or meditative context. The first member 'alaṅkata' is the past participle of alaṅkaroti, modifying 'caṅkama' which denotes a path for walking meditation.

ālambanaphalakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ālambana (sense-object or support) is qualified by phalaka (board or plank), likely referring to a panel or board used as a support or for displaying sense-objects in a technical or ritual context.

nisīdanatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of a sitting mat; for the sake of a seat
nisīdanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the dative singular, functioning adverbially to indicate purpose. nisīdanattha (sitting-mat-purpose) + āya (dative). Used to denote 'for the purpose of providing a sitting place' or similar, common in monastic contexts for seating arrangements.

caṅkamavemajjhe.meaning_2: walking meditation in the middle; centre path for walking meditation
caṅkamavemajjhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in locative singular, combining 'caṅkama' (walking meditation path) with 'vemajjhe' (in the middle), likely referring to the central path used for meditative walking in a monastic context.

muggavaṇṇasilaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound describing a stone with the color or appearance of mung beans; accusative singular form suggests use as direct object in context, likely referring to a semi-precious stone.

antopaṇṇasālāyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a compound noun 'antopaṇṇasālā', combining 'anta' (end) and 'paṇṇasālā' (monk's dwelling, lit. leaf-hall), indicating a specific monastery or hut located at the end or boundary, common in monastic contexts for peripheral dwellings.

jaṭāmaṇḍalavākacīratidaṇḍakuṇḍikādike.meaning_2: beginning with dreadlock-circle, bark-cloth, triple-rod, bent-pitcher, and so on
jaṭāmaṇḍalavākacīratidaṇḍakuṇḍikādike.family_compound: jaṭā maṇḍala vākacīra tidaṇḍa kuṇḍikā ādika
jaṭāmaṇḍalavākacīratidaṇḍakuṇḍikādike.construction: jaṭā + maṇḍala + vākacīra + tidaṇḍa + kuṇḍikā + ādika
jaṭāmaṇḍalavākacīratidaṇḍakuṇḍikādike.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a long compound in the locative singular, enumerating items such as a circle of dreadlocks (possibly a hairstyle), bark cloth garment, tripod, and bent pitcher, followed by 'and so forth,' likely referring to ascetic paraphernalia in a monastic context.

tāpasaparikkhāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in the locative singular case, likely used to describe an ascetic who possesses or is accompanied by requisites or equipment, contrasting with a fully renounced ascetic.

pānīyaghaṭapānīyasaṅkhapānīyasarāvāni.meaning_2: containers for drinking water; water jars, conch shells, and shallow dishes for drinking water
pānīyaghaṭapānīyasaṅkhapānīyasarāvāni.family_compound: pānīya ghaṭa pānīya saṅkha pānīya sarāva
pānīyaghaṭapānīyasaṅkhapānīyasarāvāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound listing various vessels used for holding drinking water, appearing in the neuter plural nominative or accusative case to denote a collective group of such items.

aṅgārakapalladāruādīnīti.meaning_2: starting with a cinder-pan and wood etc.
aṅgārakapalladāruādīnīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound serving as a list indicating items starting with 'aṅgārakapalla' (cinder-pan) and 'dāru' (wood), followed by 'ādi' (etc.) and quotative 'iti'; likely enumerating materials or objects in a Vinaya or technical context.

vissakammadevaputte.meaning_2: young deity; minor god; lit. child of god
vissakammadevaputte.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'vissakamma' (the divine architect) is qualified as a 'devaputta' (son of a god or minor deity), likely in vocative case addressing the figure in a narrative context.

himavantapabbatapāde.meaning_2: at the foot of the Himalayan mountain
himavantapabbatapāde.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where himavant modifies pabbata, and the resulting himavantapabbata is combined with pāda to indicate location at the base or foot of the Himalayas. The form shows locative singular ending -e, common for such compounds in Pāli to denote position.

girikandarānusārena.meaning_2: in accordance with the mountain gorge; following the hillside grotto
girikandarānusārena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where the instrumental adverb anusārena ('in accordance with') modifies the masculine noun girikandara ('mountain gorge').
