thutimaṅgalāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'thuti' (praise) qualifies 'maṅgala' (auspicious thing), likely referring to praises or commendations that bring auspiciousness, such as in ritual or ceremonial contexts. The form is neuter nominative/accusative plural.

payirudāhitvā.meaning_2: having covered over; having concealed; having enveloped
payirudāhitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form payirudāhitvā appears to be a sandhi variant or scribal form of paṭirudhāya hitvā or similar, but based on the provided entries, it is analyzed as an absolutive from a prefixed causative verb payirudāhati, meaning to cause to cover over or enclose. No sentences are provided for contextual meaning.

sabbītiyo.meaning_2: all misfortunes; every calamity; all adversities
sabbītiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound form functioning as a feminine noun, likely in nominative plural, denoting totality of calamities. The form sabbītiyo suggests a taddhita derivation or emphatic pluralization of the base compound sabbītim (all calamity), but treated here as direct compound inflection.

bhavantvantarāyā.meaning_2: obstacle to the respected one; danger to the master
bhavantvantarāyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bhavant' (vocative singular of bhavant, addressing a respected person) is the upapada qualifying 'antarāya' (obstacle). The form ends in long -ā due to genitive case, indicating possession or relation, as in 'obstacle of/for the respected one'. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

bodhimuttamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound used as an adjective modifying an implied neuter noun (likely 'ñāṇaṃ' or similar), describing the ultimate or supreme state of bodhi (enlightenment). The accusative singular ending indicates it is the object of a verb in the contextual sentence.

pupphino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] pupphino is the genitive singular form of the neuter noun puppha, meaning 'of the flower'. Without provided sentences, the contextual usage is assumed to follow standard Pāḷi texts where it denotes possession related to flowers.

jinabodhiyaṃ.meaning_2: conqueror's enlightenment; Bodhi tree of the Jina
jinabodhiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound 'jinabodhi', referring to the Bodhi tree or enlightenment associated with the Jina (Buddha). Used in contexts denoting the place or means of the Buddha's awakening.

puṇṇamāye.meaning_2: filled with deceit; full of illusion
puṇṇamāye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in the locative singular feminine, likely describing something characterized by being full of deceit or illusion, based on the components puṇṇa (filled, full) and māyā (deceit, illusion).

puṇṇamano.meaning_2: full-minded; having a mind full of (something, e.g. faith or joy)
puṇṇamano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where puṇṇa modifies mano, indicating a mind that is full or complete, often in contexts of positive mental states like devotion or satisfaction in Pāli literature.

dasasahassiyaṃ.meaning_2: numbering ten thousand; consisting of ten thousand
dasasahassiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dasasahassiyaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the adjective dasasahassī, used to modify a neuter noun in the accusative case, such as a collective numeral or quantity indicating 'ten thousand (of them)'.

rāhumutto.meaning_2: freed from Rāhu; released from the eclipse demon
rāhumutto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound rāhumutto is a tatpuruṣa where rāhu (the asura associated with eclipses) is the object from which release is effected, using the past participle mutto of muñcati; in context, it likely describes someone or something liberated from Rāhu's influence, metaphorically as overcoming eclipse or demonic obstruction.

thutappasattho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form thutappasattho appears to be a sandhi compound of the past participles thūta ('praised') and appasattha ('not praised'), likely functioning as a dvanda compound with a contrasting meaning such as 'praised but little praised' or 'famed yet not lauded'. Without the sentence context, the exact usage cannot be specified, but it may describe something renowned in some aspects but not fully commended.

rammanagaravāsinopi.meaning_2: even a delightful city-dweller; even an inhabitant of a charming town
rammanagaravāsinopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective used substantively with api indicating 'even', likely in a concessive sense such as 'even a resident of a delightful city' in the context of the text.

saraṇādīsu.meaning_2: beginning with shelter; etc. starting with refuge
saraṇādīsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative plural form of the indeclinable compound saraṇādi, used in lists to mean 'in things beginning with shelter/refuge', often in Buddhist contexts referring to the Three Refuges (Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha) and so on.

rammanagaramhā.meaning_2: from a delightful town; from a charming city
rammanagaramhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the ablative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound 'rammanagara' (delightful town), where 'ramma' is the past participle of √ram used adjectivally, agreeing with the neuter noun 'nagara'. The sandhi at the compound boundary changes 'rammaṃ nagaraṃ' to 'rammanagaraṃ', and the ablative ending -amhā follows.

vuttañhi.meaning_2: as was said; indeed, it was said
vuttañhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a common Pāḷi adverbial expression combining the past participle 'vutta' (from √vac, 'said') with the emphatic particle 'hi' ('indeed'), used to introduce a reference to something previously stated in the text, such as a quote or earlier doctrine.

bhojayitvāna.meaning_2: having fed; having given food to
bhojayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Absolutive form indicating a completed action prior to the main verb, commonly used in narrative sequences to denote 'after having done something'.

phalamuttame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely meaning 'the best fruit' or 'supreme consequence' in a metaphorical sense, common in Pāḷi for denoting the highest outcome or reward.

varasamāpattiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Plural form (nominative/accusative) of a tatpuruṣa compound 'vara-samāpatti' meaning 'excellent attainment', likely referring to advanced meditative states in Buddhist context.

mahāhanusabhakkhandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound referring to a large aggregation or mass associated with a 'non-leader' or 'non-chief' (anusabha, lit. 'not a bull' metaphorically); the exact contextual usage would depend on the missing sentence, but it likely denotes a substantial group or pile in a narrative or doctrinal sense.

dīpaṅkarasanāmako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a vocative singular of a compound adjective meaning 'O one named Dīpaṅkara', likely addressing the Buddha Dīpaṅkara. The ending -ako is a taddhita suffix forming an adjective from nāma 'name', with ko as a secondary masculine suffix.

upagantvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upagantvāna shows sandhi with a following word beginning in a vowel, where -ā + a- becomes -āna; common in Pāḷi texts for gerunds followed by enclitics or vowels.

paṭhamābhisamaye.meaning_2: first complete comprehension; initial breakthrough; first total understanding
paṭhamābhisamaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound where 'paṭhama' (first) modifies 'abhisamaya' (complete comprehension), likely referring to the initial moment of enlightenment or understanding in a Buddhist context, such as the first attainment of insight.

koṭisatamabodhayi.meaning_2: one who has enlightened a hundred thousand (beings)
koṭisatamabodhayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (tatpuruṣa) where koṭi-satama means 'hundred thousand' and bodhayī is an agent noun from the causative root budh, meaning 'enlightener'. The form koṭisatamabodhayi is a sandhi variant of the nominative singular koṭisatamabodhayī.

dutiyābhisamaye.meaning_2: at the second breakthrough; on the second occasion of complete comprehension
dutiyābhisamaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'dutiyābhisamaya' meaning 'second breakthrough' or 'second complete comprehension', likely referring to a sequential attainment in spiritual context, such as the second insight in Buddhist stages of enlightenment. The form shows sandhi with ā from dutiyā and a from abhisamaya contracting to ā.

navutikoṭimabodhayi.meaning_2: one who teaches the ninety koṭis of dhammas; enlightener of the ninety koṭi teachings
navutikoṭimabodhayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound referring to a teacher or revealer of the vast corpus of 90 koṭis (myriads) of Buddhist doctrines, likely in a Mahāyāna or cosmological context.

dhammamadesayi.meaning_2: taught the doctrine; explained the teaching
dhammamadesayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dhammamadesayi is a sandhi contraction of dhammaṃ + adesayi, where the accusative dhammaṃ (the teaching/doctrine) is the direct object of the causative aorist 'taught/explained'. This usage aligns with dhamma 1.03 (teaching; doctrine) in the context of expounding Buddhist principles.

navutikoṭisahassānaṃ.meaning_2: of ninety ten billions (of ninety times ten billion)
navutikoṭisahassānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the genitive plural form of the large cardinal number 'navutikoṭisahassa', denoting ninety koṭis (each koṭi being 10 million) times a thousand, resulting in 90 × 10,000,000,000 = 900,000,000,000. Used likely in enumerating vast quantities, such as beings or worlds in cosmological contexts.

tatiyābhisamayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'tatiyā' (feminine instrumental of 'tatiya', meaning 'third') modifies 'abhisamayo' (masculine nominative singular of 'abhisamaya', meaning 'complete comprehension'). The form 'tatiyābhisamayo' results from sandhi resolution, adjusting the final -ā of tatiyā with the initial a- of abhisamayo to ābhi- while preserving the nominative masculine ending -o. It likely refers to the third stage of insight or enlightenment in Buddhist contexts.

nāradakūṭamhi.meaning_2: in the deceit of Nārada; in the trap of Nārada
nāradakūṭamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a locative singular form of a compound noun 'nāradakūṭa' meaning 'the fraud/deceit of Nārada', where Nārada refers to the monk, and kūṭa denotes deceit or trap. The context suggests a narrative involving deception associated with this figure.

pavivekagate.meaning_2: gone to solitude; having entered seclusion; devoted to seclusion
pavivekagate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'paviveka' (seclusion) with 'gata' (gone to), indicating a state of having attained or resorted to solitude, likely describing a monk or person in a secluded state.

satakoṭiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A compound numeral denoting 100 × 10,000,000 = 1,000,000,000, used in large enumerations typical of Pāli texts, especially in cosmology or listings of eons.

sudassanasiluccaye.meaning_2: beautiful mountain; lit. good to see + hill
sudassanasiluccaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative singular, likely referring to a specific beautiful or splendid mountain in a narrative context, combining the adjective 'sudassana' (beautiful) with 'siluccaya' (hill or mountain).

navutikoṭisahassehi.meaning_2: with ninety times ten billion; with nine hundred billion
navutikoṭisahassehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound cardinal number, indicating 'with' a vast quantity, likely referring to beings or entities in a cosmological or enumerative context typical of Pāḷi texts.

uggatāpano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound adjective combining 'ugga' (mighty, powerful) with 'tāpana' (scorching, tormenting), likely used to describe something formidable and burning or intense in a metaphorical sense, such as a fierce heat or affliction, though no specific sentence context is provided.

dasavīsasahassānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral meaning 'twenty thousand' in the genitive plural, used to indicate possession or relation to twenty thousand items, likely worlds or similar in Buddhist context.

ekadvinnaṃ.grammar: card, gen du of eka dvi
ekadvinnaṃ.meaning_2: of one two; of a pair
ekadvinnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvandva compound numeral indicating duality, likely 'of one and two' or 'of the pair', but in Pāḷi context often simplified to 'of two'. Without the sentence, the exact usage is inferred from form.

rammavatī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word rammavatī appears to be a feminine adjective formed by combining the present participle ramma (charming, delightful, from √ram) with the suffix -vatī (possessing the quality of, dutiful, from vata). It likely means 'one who is charming' or 'possessing charm', used as a feminine noun. No contextual sentences provided to refine the meaning.

sudevo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound combining the prefix 'su' (good, well) with 'deva' (deity, god), forming a masculine noun in the vocative singular form. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

sunandā.meaning_2: lady of good fortune; auspicious woman
sunandā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word sunandā is a compound combining the prefix su- ('good, auspicious') with nanda ('happy, joyful'), forming a feminine noun likely referring to a woman or deity embodying happiness or good fortune. No specific contextual sentence provided, but it parallels entries like nandā as names of arahant nuns.

asītihatthamubbedho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound indicating a height measurement of eighty cubits, commonly used in Pāli texts for dimensions of structures or beings; asīti (eighty) modifies hattha (cubit), and ubbedho provides the sense of 'height' or 'extension upward'.

dīparukkhova.meaning_2: like a tree in an island; like a tree on land
dīparukkhova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dīparukkhova is a sandhi compound where dīpa (island or land) + rukkha (tree) + iva (like), with eva as an emphatic particle. It appears to be in nominative singular, used metaphorically to compare something to a tree situated on an island or solid ground, possibly symbolizing stability or refuge.

sālarājāva.meaning_2: king of the sal tree; sal tree king only
sālarājāva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a descriptive compound referring to a king associated with or likened to the sal tree (Shorea robusta), possibly in a metaphorical or titular sense; the 'eva' adds emphasis, suggesting exclusivity or specificity in context.

satasahassavassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound numeral expressing duration, inflected in neuter accusative plural to agree with an implied object such as 'vassāni' meaning 'years'.

tamantarahitaṃ.grammar: nt acc sg of tamantarahita, comp
tamantarahitaṃ.meaning_2: disappeared from that; vanished from it; bereft of that
tamantarahitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an inflected compound adjective, accusative singular neuter, likely functioning adverbially or as a predicate in context, meaning 'having disappeared from that' or 'without that'. The prefix taṃ (acc. of 'that') combines with antarahita (past participle of antardhāyati, 'to disappear').

paṭhamasannipāte.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound form in locative singular, likely referring to 'in the first assembly' or 'in the first gathering' in a grammatical or textual context, such as the first section of a text or collection.

navutikoṭiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form navutikoṭiyo is the feminine singular nominative of the compound numeral, equivalent to 90 × 10,000,000 = 900,000,000. The -o- is a typical linking vowel in Pāli numeral compounds.

koṭisatasahassasaṅkhassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound denoting a vast number, literally 'a conch (saṅkha) of one billion (koṭisatasahassa)', used in Pāli to express immense quantities, often in cosmological or enumerative contexts. The form is genitive singular, indicating possession or relation.

sunando.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sunando is a present participle with the prefix su- intensifying the root √nand 'to rejoice'. No contextual sentences provided, but it typically denotes a state of thorough joy or delight in Pāḷi texts.

sālakalyāṇī.meaning_2: auspicious sal tree; blessed sal tree
sālakalyāṇī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A feminine compound noun formed from 'sāla' (sal tree, Shorea robusta) and 'kalyāṇī' (auspicious, excellent, or beautiful woman), likely denoting an auspicious or blessed sal tree in a metaphorical or literal sense, possibly personified.

aṭṭhāsītihatthubbedhaṃ.meaning_2: eighty-cubit depth; depth of eighty cubits
aṭṭhāsītihatthubbedhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound describing a measurement of depth equivalent to eighty cubits, likely in the context of a well, pit, or similar structure. The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the direct object in the sentence.

anantatejo.meaning_2: of infinite radiance; of boundless splendor
anantatejo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound adjective in the bahuvrīhi style, where tejo (radiance, splendor) is qualified by anantatā (limitlessness), forming 'that whose radiance is infinite'. Likely used in a descriptive context for divine or exalted qualities, such as in Buddhist or Vedic literature praising enlightenment or divine attributes.

vemātikabhātā.meaning_2: brothers having a different mother and the same father; half-brothers (paternal)
vemātikabhātā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa sandhi compound where 'vemātika' (half-brother/sister, lit. 'different mother') modifies 'bhātā' (brother). The form 'vemātikabhātā' appears to be nominative plural, referring to paternal half-brothers in a familial or legal context, common in Vinaya discussions of relationships.

ānandakumāro.meaning_2: Ānanda the prince; the young prince named Ānanda
ānandakumāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound form in vocative singular, addressing a young prince named Ānanda, likely referring to a figure such as the Buddha's attendant in his youth or a royal context. The form ānandakumāro follows standard Pāḷi declension for masculine compounds ending in -a.

navutikoṭisaṅkhāya.meaning_1: to the calculation of ninety koṭis
navutikoṭisaṅkhāya.meaning_2: ninety million; ninety times ten million; to the reckoning of ninety koṭis
navutikoṭisaṅkhāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the feminine dative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound navutikoṭisaṅkhā, where navutikoṭi means 'ninety koṭis' (90 × 10,000,000 = 900,000,000), and saṅkhā refers to calculation or enumeration, common in Buddhist texts for large numbers in enumerative contexts like eons or beings.

iddhimayapattacīvarassa.meaning_2: bowl and robe made of psychic power; supernormal robe and bowl
iddhimayapattacīvarassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'mayapattacīvara' means 'bowl and robe made of', qualified by 'iddhi' in the sense of psychic power. The genitive ending -assa indicates possession or relation, likely 'of the bowl and robe produced by psychic power' in a monastic context.

iddhimayapattacīvaradharā.meaning_2: wearing a bowl and robe made of psychic power; possessing supernormal robe and bowl
iddhimayapattacīvaradharā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound in feminine form, likely modifying a noun like bhikkhunī or devatā in the context of supernormal attainments. The core meaning revolves around iddhi as psychic power, with the robe and bowl being miraculously produced through such powers, a common motif in Pāli narratives about arahants or deities.

saṭṭhivassamahātherā.meaning_2: great elder of sixty years standing
saṭṭhivassamahātherā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound, referring to a senior monk who has been ordained for sixty years.

asītihatthappamāṇāyeva.meaning_2: only eighty cubits in measure; merely a span of eighty hand-lengths
asītihatthappamāṇāyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound used as an adverbial phrase, likely indicating the limited or immeasurable size in a hyperbolic sense, such as the breadth of a path or space being 'only' eighty cubits, emphasizing its vastness despite the numerical limit.

rukkhapathavipabbatasamuddādayo.meaning_2: beginning with trees, earth, mountains, and oceans; etc.
rukkhapathavipabbatasamuddādayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda-samāsa compound followed by 'ādi' indicating 'and so forth'. The ending '-ādayo' is the nominative plural masculine of 'ādi', agreeing with the masculine members of the list (rukkha, pabbata, samudda).

ukkhalikādīni.meaning_2: small cooking pots etc.; and the like starting with small cooking pot
ukkhalikādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a neuter plural form of the compound ukkhalikādi, used in a list to indicate 'small cooking pot and the like,' typical in Pāḷi for enumerating categories with etc.

suvaṇṇapaṭṭapariyonaddhā.meaning_1: covered with a golden slab; enveloped in gold plate
suvaṇṇapaṭṭapariyonaddhā.meaning_2: wrapped in golden cloth; overlaid with gold leaf
suvaṇṇapaṭṭapariyonaddhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective in feminine nominative singular, likely modifying a feminine noun such as 'ekā' or similar in the missing sentence context, indicating something fully wrapped or covered with a golden plate or slab.

navutivassasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter plural accusative form of a compound numeral adjective used substantively to denote a large span of time, likely referring to a cosmic or legendary duration in the context of the text.

candimasūriyādayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound ending in ādi, indicating 'moon, sun and others' or 'beginning with moon and sun'. The -o ending suggests locative plural in a list or enumeration context, common in Pāḷi for specifying categories like celestial bodies.

virocituṃ.meaning_2: to shine; to glitter; to appear
virocituṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form virocituṃ is an infinitive used to express purpose or result in the context of shining or manifesting, common in poetic or descriptive passages.

rattindivaparicchedo.meaning_2: boundary of day and night; limit between night and day
rattindivaparicchedo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'rattindiva' (day and night) as the upapada with 'pariccheda' (boundary, limit), indicating the demarcation or division between night and day. The form is nominative singular masculine, likely subject in the sentence.

buddhālokeneva.meaning_2: just like with the light of the Buddha
buddhālokeneva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound buddhaloka 'light of the Buddha' combined with iva 'like' and eva 'just', forming an adverbial phrase indicating similitude with the Buddha's light.

pupphitakusumānaṃ.meaning_2: of the blossomed flowers; of the blooming blossoms
pupphitakusumānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where pupphita (past participle 'blossomed') modifies kusuma ('flower'), in genitive plural form. Likely used in a descriptive context referring to flowers that have bloomed.

ravanakasakuṇādīnañca.meaning_2: and the like of the sound and the bird
ravanakasakuṇādīnañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form of a karmadhāraya compound 'ravanakasakuṇādi' (sound-bird etc.) in the genitive plural neuter, combined with the enclitic 'ca' (and). It refers to various sounds such as those of birds and similar things.

rattindivaparicchedaṃ.meaning_2: delimitation of day and night; distinction between night and day
rattindivaparicchedaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'rattindiva' (day and night) with 'pariccheda' (delimitation), likely referring to the conceptual or temporal boundary distinguishing night from day in a classificatory or definitional context.

pubbapatthanāvasena.meaning_2: by means of previous intention; according to prior aspiration
pubbapatthanāvasena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi compound used instrumentally to indicate the manner or basis of an action, specifically referring to intention or aspiration established previously. In Pāḷi texts, such compounds often describe motivational or preparatory aspects in ethical or doctrinal contexts.

bodhisattacariyakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the bodhisatta's conduct; during the period of the Buddha-to-be's virtuous deeds
bodhisattacariyakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'bodhisattacariyakāla' meaning 'the time of the bodhisatta's conduct', used adverbially to indicate 'at that time' in the context of the aspirant Buddha's life of practice and perfection.

vessantarasadise.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something likened to Vessantara, the renowned prince known for his supreme generosity in the Jātaka tale. In context, it likely refers to a quality or action resembling Vessantara's unparalleled giving.

vaṅkapabbatasadise.meaning_2: resembling a bent mountain; like a crooked hill
vaṅkapabbatasadise.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective in the locative singular, used to compare something to a mountain that is bent or crooked in shape.

atheko.meaning_2: and then; or; after that; because of
atheko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'atheko' appears to be a sandhi combination of the indeclinable 'atha' (then; or) and 'eko' (masculine nominative singular of 'eka', meaning 'one' or 'a certain'). It likely functions as an adverbial expression equivalent to 'and then one' or 'or a certain one', possibly introducing a subsequent item or alternative in a list or narrative context.

kharadāṭhiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a descriptive compound combining 'khara' (rough, harsh) with 'dāṭhika' (having teeth or fangs), likely referring to something with rough or jagged teeth. No contextual sentences provided, so meaning is inferred from components.

dānajjhāsayataṃ.grammar: fem, in comps, from dāna + ajjhāsaya
dānajjhāsayataṃ.meaning_2: fact of having the intention of giving; intention to give; desire to bestow
dānajjhāsayataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a feminine abstract noun, expressing the quality or state of intending to give, often in contexts of generosity or charitable intent in Pāḷi texts.

mūlakalāpe.meaning_2: quail rooted in the radish; radish quail; quail of the root
mūlakalāpe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound mūlakalāpe is the locative singular of mūlakalāpa, likely a descriptive compound (tatpuruṣa) where mūlaka (radish or root-related) qualifies kalāpa (bundle or group). In the absence of sentences, it may refer to a quail associated with radish roots, perhaps a type of bird or a metaphorical expression; 'chatterer rooted in the radish' if lāpa is considered, but kalāpa fits better morphologically with the long ā.

vivaṭamatte.meaning_2: in the measure of what is uncovered; to the extent of what is revealed
vivaṭamatte.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vivaṭa (past participle, 'uncovered, revealed') is qualified by matta (instrumental sense, 'in the measure of, to the extent of'). The form is neuter nominative/accusative singular, likely used adverbially in context to indicate degree or manner related to revelation or clarification.

aggijālaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word aggijālaṃ is the accusative singular of a compound noun combining 'aggi' (fire) and 'jāla' (net), likely referring to a fiery net or infernal snare in a metaphorical or mythological context, such as in descriptions of hell or punishment.

lohitadhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form lohitadhāraṃ is the accusative singular neuter of the compound lohita-dhārā, where lohita ('blood') qualifies dhārā ('stream, flow'), indicating a flow or stream of blood, likely in a poetic or metaphorical sense as in Vedic or epic literature.

uggiramānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form uggiramānaṃ is the accusative singular masculine/neuter present active participle of uggirati, likely used adjectivally in context to describe something or someone in the act of raising or uttering, depending on the specific usage in the text.

aparampissa.grammar: pron, masc & nt dat sg of apara
aparampissa.meaning_2: to another; for another; to some other; for some other
aparampissa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aparampissa combines the adverbial accusative aparaṃ ('another, furthermore') with the enclitic genitive-datival pronoun -ssa ('to him/for him'), yielding a sense like 'to him furthermore' or 'for another one.' Without context, it likely functions as a dative construction emphasizing 'to another' in a narrative or doctrinal context, possibly in Vinaya texts discussing sequential or alternative cases.

bodhisattakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the bodhisatta; in the bodhisatta period
bodhisattakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative form of the tatpuruṣa compound bodhisattakāla 'bodhisatta-time'. The locative ending -e indicates 'at the time of', referring to the period when someone is a bodhisatta, i.e., before attaining full Buddhahood.

daṇḍadīpikāveṭhananiyāmena.meaning_2: by the prescribed method of wrapping the torch; in the manner of binding the staff-torch
daṇḍadīpikāveṭhananiyāmena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an instrumental adverbial form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely used in a technical or ritual context to describe a specific procedure for wrapping or binding a torch (daṇḍadīpikā) with a turban-like covering (veṭhana) according to a fixed rule (niyāmena). No contextual sentence is provided, so the interpretation relies on the dictionary entries.

veṭhāpetvā.meaning_2: having caused to be rolled; having caused to be enveloped
veṭhāpetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Causative absolutive form indicating prior action of causing something to be twisted or bound.

ratanamattamakuḷaṃ.meaning_2: crest consisting of a quantity of jewels; jeweled crown
ratanamattamakuḷaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'ratana' (jewel) is quantified by 'matta' (amount of, measure of), modifying 'makuḷa' (crest, crown), indicating a crown or crest adorned with a certain measure of jewels. The form is accusative singular neuter, likely functioning as an object or adjective in the sentence.

satasahassagghanikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter accusative singular form of a compound adjective meaning 'worth a hundred thousand' or 'valued at one hundred thousand'. The form ends in -kaṃ due to the final member -ika, which takes the short -a stem in neuter.

sahassavaṭṭiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sahassavaṭṭiyo is the nominative plural of a compound adjective sahassavaṭṭī, where sahassa means 'thousand' and vaṭṭi refers to 'fold' or 'layer' in a numerical sense, similar to Sanskrit sahasravatī. This construction denotes multiplicity or abundance in a thousand ways, often used figuratively in Pāḷi literature to express vastness.

jālāpetvā.meaning_2: having caused to cry out; having made to scream
jālāpetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form jalāpetvā is the gerund of the denominative verb jalāpeti, formed from ja (cry) + the causative of lapeti (to speak, cause to speak), meaning to cause to cry out or scream. It indicates an action completed before the main verb in the sentence.

sīsenādāya.grammar: ind, adv, instr sg of sīsa + ger of ādiyati
sīsenādāya.meaning_2: having taken the head; after taking the head; having the head
sīsenādāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This form appears to be a fused adverbial construction combining the instrumental singular of 'sīsa' (head) with the gerund of 'ādiyati' (to take), functioning as an indeclinable adverb indicating manner or accompaniment involving the head. Without context sentences, the precise usage is inferred from dictionary entries; it may describe an action like 'with the head taken' in ritual or metaphorical contexts.

vāyamantassāpissa.meaning_1: making an effort (to); striving (for); exerting oneself (to)
vāyamantassāpissa.construction: vi + ā + yama + nta + ssa + api + ssa
vāyamantassāpissa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a sandhi combination of 'vāyamantassa' (gen.dat.sg.masc. of the present participle 'vāyamantā') + 'api' (emphatic indeclinable 'indeed, also') + 'assa' (gen.dat.sg.masc. of 'ima', 'his' or 'to him'), likely resulting from euphonic changes in connected speech or a compound form. Without the full sentence, the exact contextual nuance of 'api' (e.g., 'even' or 'surely') and the referent of 'assa' cannot be specified, but it describes someone or something 'striving for him' or 'his striving indeed'.

lomakūpamattampi.meaning_2: even to the extent of a hair follicle; even the merest amount of a hair's breadth
lomakūpamattampi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi form functioning as an indeclinable emphasizing a negligible quantity, idiomatically 'not even a hair's breadth,' derived from the compound lomakūpamatta 'measured by a hair follicle' plus api 'even.' The exact contextual sentence is unavailable, but it likely negates any small degree or interval in a prohibitive or emphatic sense.

paviṭṭhakālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from the past participle paviṭṭha ('entered') and kāla ('time'), likely denoting the moment or period of entering something, such as a state, place, or phase. Without contextual sentences, the precise usage is inferred from the components.

sarīrobhāso.meaning_2: appearance of the body; bodily manifestation; radiance of the body
sarīrobhāso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sarīrabhāso combines 'sarīra' (body) with 'bhāsa' (shining, radiance), suggesting a bodily appearance or aura. Without specific sentences, the meaning is inferred from dictionary entries; it likely denotes the visible or radiant form of the physical body in contexts like description or meditation.

madhuradhammakathaṃ.meaning_2: sweet discourse on the Dhamma; lovely discussion about the nature of things
madhuradhammakathaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely used as the direct object in a sentence describing a pleasant or endearing talk on the Buddha's teachings.

parivārabhikkhūti.meaning_2: monk of the retinue; monk of the entourage
parivārabhikkhūti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form parivārabhikkhūti appears to be a sandhi combination of parivārabhikkhu + iti, where the instrumental singular parivārabhikkhū (parivārabhikkh + ū) contracts with iti. In Vinaya contexts, this likely refers to a monk belonging to the Buddha's or a teacher's retinue, used in quotative or definitional phrases.

paṭhamasannipātoyeva.meaning_2: only the first assembly; merely the initial gathering
paṭhamasannipātoyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound functioning as an adverbial phrase, likely referring to the initial collection or assembly in a textual or grammatical context, with 'eva' adding emphasis on exclusivity.

yāgubhattavatthādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a neuter plural form of a compound noun ending in ādi, indicating a list starting with rice gruel, boiled rice/food, and cloth, and so on; likely referring to items of material support or requisites in a Vinaya context.

nisīdanaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_1: place for sitting; seat; sitting position
nisīdanaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: place of sitting; seat; location for sitting
nisīdanaṭṭhānaṃ.construction: ni + sīda + ana + ṭhān + ana + aṃ
nisīdanaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where nisīdana ('sitting') modifies ṭhāna ('place'), forming 'place for/of sitting'. The accusative singular ending -ṃ indicates it as the object in the sentence. The meaning aligns with physical seating arrangements in monastic contexts, such as a designated spot for meditation or rest.

caturāsītiyojanasahassamatthake.meaning_1: (from here) a distance of eighty-four thousand yojanas
caturāsītiyojanasahassamatthake.meaning_2: at a distance of approximately 1,680,000 kilometers; lit. at the top of eighty-four thousand yojanas
caturāsītiyojanasahassamatthake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial compound uses the locative singular of 'matthaka' to idiomatically express distance, similar to 'yojanamatthe' but with a more literal 'at the top' connotation. The yojana is an ancient Indian unit roughly 12-15 km, making the total distance immense, often hyperbolic in Pāli literature for remote or mythical locations.

paṇḍukambalasilāsanassa.meaning_2: seat of the pale woollen rock; throne in Tāvatiṃsa heaven
paṇḍukambalasilāsanassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form indicating possession or association with the throne in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, combining the place name paṇḍukambalasilā with asana meaning seat.

uṇhabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of heat; condition of being hot; heat
uṇhabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely used in a context describing the state or condition of heat, such as in physical or metaphorical senses in Pāḷi texts.

nisīdanaṭṭhānatthāya.meaning_1: for the sake of a place for sitting
nisīdanaṭṭhānatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of a sitting place; for the benefit of a seat
nisīdanaṭṭhānatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the dative case used adverbially, indicating purpose. 'Nisīdana' refers to the act or instrument of sitting, 'ṭhāna' to place or location, and 'atthāya' to 'for the sake of'. In context, it likely denotes arranging or providing a seat or sitting arrangement.

puññakoṭṭhāsaṃ.meaning_2: portion of merit; share of good deeds; component of spiritual wealth
puññakoṭṭhāsaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form puññakoṭṭhāsaṃ appears to be an accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely meaning 'a portion of merit' in contexts discussing spiritual or ethical components; the exact contextual usage cannot be determined without the provided sentences.

vaḍḍhakivaṇṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is an inflected form (accusative singular) of a tatpuruṣa compound 'vaḍḍhakī-vaṇṇa', denoting the social class or caste associated with the profession of carpentry. The first member 'vaḍḍhakī' is the agent noun for carpenter, derived from 'vaḍḍhaka'; the second 'vaṇṇa' refers to caste (meaning 1.05). No contextual sentences provided, but in Pāli texts, such compounds often describe occupational groups in societal contexts.

vāsipharasuhattho.meaning_2: axe in hand; holding an axe
vāsipharasuhattho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'vāsipharasa' (axe) is the object held in 'hattha' (hand). 'Vāsi' refers to a type of axe or cutting tool, combined with 'pharasu' (axe) as a tatpuruṣa specifying the kind of axe. The form is likely instrumental or locative in context, indicating possession or action of holding.

ajānanasippaṃ.meaning_2: ignorance of skill; lack of knowledge in a craft
ajānanasippaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ajānana (ignorance) modifies sippa (skill), indicating a state of not knowing or ignorance regarding skills or crafts. The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the object in the sentence.

koṭisatasahassabhikkhū.meaning_2: one billion monks; one trillion monks
koṭisatasahassabhikkhū.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is nominative plural of the compound, indicating a vast number of monks in the context of the text.

nisīdanamaṇḍapaṃ.meaning_2: pavilion for sitting; seated hall; sitting tent
nisīdanamaṇḍapaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining nisīdana (sitting mat or act of sitting) with maṇḍapa (pavilion), likely referring to a pavilion or hall used for sitting or assembly, common in monastic contexts without a specific sentence provided.

dvādasaterasayojanappamāṇo.meaning_2: of immeasurable extent of twelve or thirteen yojanas; measuring approximately 240-260 kilometers
dvādasaterasayojanappamāṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a distance that is boundless or approximate in the range of twelve to thirteen yojanas, each yojana being about 20 km; the dual numbering suggests an estimation or variability in measurement.

samatalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Samatalo is a bahuvrīhi compound describing something possessing equal level surfaces, often used in contexts of flatness or equality in elevation.

sattaratanamayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sattaratanamayo is the nominative singular masculine of the compound adjective sattaratnamaya, derived from sattaratana ('seven treasures') + maya ('made of'). It describes something constructed or built from the seven precious substances (gold, silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, etc.) revered in Buddhist texts.

rajatamayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'rajata' (silver) is the material and 'maya' (made of) indicates composition. Used adjectivally to describe something constructed from silver.

rajatamayesu.meaning_2: made of silver; constructed of silver
rajatamayesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form indicating 'in those made of silver'; the compound combines 'rajata' (silver) with 'maya' (made of), referring to objects constructed from silver material.

maṇitthambhesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word maṇitthambhesu is the locative plural form of the compound maṇitthambha, meaning 'in the jeweled pillars' or 'among the gemstone columns'. It combines maṇi ('jewel; gemstone') and thambha ('pillar; column'), likely referring to ornate architectural supports in a descriptive context.

pavāḷamayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word pavāḷamayā is the feminine instrumental singular form of the adjective pavāḷamaya, derived from the neuter noun pavāḷa ('coral') and the suffix -maya ('made of'), indicating something constructed or built from coral. The instrumental case suggests agency or material composition in context.

pavāḷatthambhesu.meaning_2: coral pillar; pillar made of coral
pavāḷatthambhesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pavāḷatthambhesu exhibits sandhi where intervocalic 'a' of thambha is elided, resulting in pavāḷa + tthambha > pavāḷatthambha. Likely locative plural, indicating location 'on/in coral pillars', common in descriptive contexts of architecture or settings in Pāḷi literature.

sattaratanamayesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sattaratanamayesu is the locative plural of the compound adjective sattaratanamaya used substantively, indicating 'in those made of the seven treasures' or 'among the items constructed from the seven treasures'. The base sattaratana refers to the canonical seven treasures (gold, silver, etc.) in Buddhist contexts.

sattaratanamayāva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sattaratanamayāva appears to be a sandhi-affected instrumental singular of sattaratanan ('seven treasures') modified by mayā ('by me') with eva ('indeed') for emphasis. Likely context: 'indeed by me (made) of the seven treasures' or similar, indicating something constructed from the seven jewels.

antarantarena.grammar: ind, prep, ins sg of antara
antarantarena.meaning_2: between; among; in the interval of; in the midst of
antarantarena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form antarantarena is the instrumental singular of the indeclinable preposition antara, used to indicate position or relation 'between' or 'among'. In Pāḷi, such prepositional forms often govern the instrumental case to express spatial or relational intervals.

mandavāteritassa.meaning_2: stirred by a gentle breeze; wind-swept by soft wind
mandavāteritassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form mandavāteritassa is genitive singular masculine or neuter of the compound adjective mandavāterita, likely describing something affected by a gentle breeze, combining 'manda' (gentle, soft) with 'vāterita' (stirred by wind).

madhurasaddo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'madhura' (sweet, lovely) qualifies 'sadda' (sound, voice), likely referring to a melodious or pleasant sound in the context of the text.

dibbasaṅgītivattanakālo.meaning_2: time of divine communal recitation and conduct
dibbasaṅgītivattanakālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound referring to a specific period or occasion involving heavenly or divine group chanting/recitation and adherence to conduct, possibly in a Buddhist or ritual context.

gandhadāmamālādāmāni.meaning_2: garlands and wreaths of fragrant flowers
gandhadāmamālādāmāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a dvanda compound enumerating types of floral decorations: 'garlands and wreaths of fragrant flowers'. The ending -āni indicates neuter nominative or accusative plural. The repetition of dāma may emphasize variety or be a stylistic feature in the context.

koṭisatasahassasaṅkhānaṃ.meaning_2: of a billion trillions; of an inconceivably large number
koṭisatasahassasaṅkhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the genitive singular of a compound numeral indicating an astronomically large quantity, typical in Pāli texts for hyperbolic enumeration of merits or beings. 'Saṅkhāna' here refers to a unit of calculation, amplifying the numerical scale beyond koṭisatasahassa (10^12).

olokentassevassa.grammar: prp of oloketi, dat sg + ind
olokentassevassa.construction: ava + loke + nta + ssa + eva + ssa
olokentassevassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi combination of 'olokentassa' (dative singular of the present participle 'olokenta', meaning 'to the observing one') and 'evassa' (indeclinable 'eva' + genitive/dative 'assa' from pronoun 'ima', meaning 'of it' or 'to it'). This creates an emphatic adverbial phrase indicating 'observing it indeed' or 'just looking at it', common in Pāḷi for emphasis in narrative contexts.

olokayato.meaning_2: having been seen; having been looked at
olokayato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form olokayato is the past passive participle in the ablative singular neuter, indicating 'from that which has been seen' or 'from the object seen'. In Pāḷi, oloketi is a denominative verb derived from lok 'world' or 'sight', meaning 'to look at' or 'to behold'.

sakkabhavanaṃ.meaning_2: dwelling of Sakka; abode of the king of the Devas
sakkabhavanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sakka' (Sakka, the king of the Devas) qualifies 'bhavana' (dwelling). The accusative singular ending -ṃ indicates it as the direct object in the sentence.

bāhirakadānañhi.meaning_2: giving to outsiders; offering to non-Buddhists
bāhirakadānañhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely refers to the act of giving alms or offerings to non-Buddhists or outsiders, which in Buddhist Vinaya contexts is often discussed in relation to proper recipients of dana.

alaṅkatasīsaṃ.meaning_2: having a head that is dressed up or adorned
alaṅkatasīsaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective functioning as a bahuvrīhi, describing something characterized by a head that is adorned; the accusative singular form suggests it modifies a masculine or neuter noun in the accusative case. The primary sense of sīsa as 'head' is most appropriate here, given the context of adornment.

añjitaakkhīni.meaning_2: eyes anointed with collyrium; eyes with ointment
añjitaakkhīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound where añjita describes the eyes; the form akkhīni is accusative plural of akkhi (eye), functioning as the head of the compound.

dinnakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the offering; at the time of the gift; at the time of the donation
dinnakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'dinna' (nt pp of dadāti, meaning 'offering' or 'gift') qualifies 'kāla' (masc, meaning 'time'), resulting in a masculine noun denoting the specific time associated with the offering. The locative singular form 'dinnakāle' indicates 'at the time of the offering'. In Vinaya contexts, this often refers to the time when alms or gifts are given, such as during meal times or donation ceremonies.

kahāpaṇasatasahassāni.meaning_2: 100,000 silver coins; a vast sum of money
kahāpaṇasatasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'one hundred thousand silver coins,' likely used to denote an immense wealth or fine in a legal or narrative context, as no specific sentence is provided.

nagaramajjhe.meaning_1: in the middle of the town; in the midst of the city
nagaramajjhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where the locative singular of nagara ('nagre') sandhies with majjhe ('in the middle'), resulting in nagaramajjhe, meaning 'in the midst of the town'. The form reflects common Pāḷi sandhi rules for compounds involving locatives.

cāgatuṭṭhiṃ.meaning_2: contentment with giving up; satisfaction with generosity; happiness in relinquishing
cāgatuṭṭhiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound noun formed from cāga (giving up, generosity) and tuṭṭhi (contentment, satisfaction). In Pāḷi texts, such compounds often denote a state of being content with or satisfied by the first member. Without specific sentences, the meaning is inferred as a psychological state related to renunciation or sharing.

ghanapākapakke.meaning_2: compact boiled rice; thickly cooked rice
ghanapākapakke.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound adjective used substantively, referring to a type of dense or compact cooked rice preparation, likely in a culinary or ritual context.

pakkamadhusakkarācuṇṇasappīhi.meaning_2: with cooked honey-sugar-powder-ghee; with a medicinal preparation of ghee, honey, sugar, and powder
pakkamadhusakkarācuṇṇasappīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound used in a medical or Vinaya context, likely referring to a mixture for treating wounds or illness, where 'pakka' indicates cooked or prepared, 'madhu' honey, 'sakkarā' sugar, 'cuṇṇa' powder, and 'sappī' ghee.

parivisituṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form parivisituṃ is an infinitive derived from the causative of the root √viś (to enter), with the prefix pari meaning 'around'. It denotes the action of causing something to enter around, i.e., surrounding. Without contextual sentences, the exact usage is inferred from standard Vinaya and sutta contexts where it often describes encircling or attending around.

dvādasaterasayojanappamāṇaṃ.meaning_2: measuring twelve and thirteen yojanas; approximately 240 to 260 kilometers
dvādasaterasayojanappamāṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound indicating a measurement spanning twelve to thirteen yojanas, used in a context describing an extensive distance, such as the length of a journey or boundary.

pariyosānadivase.meaning_2: on the concluding day; on the final day
pariyosānadivase.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the compound 'pariyosānadivasa', meaning 'on the day of conclusion' or 'on the final day', likely referring to the last day of a period, event, or observance in the context of the text.

sabbabhikkhūnaṃ.meaning_2: of all monks; of every monk
sabbabhikkhūnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in the dative plural form, likely referring to 'to/for all monks' in a Vinaya or monastic context, as bhikkhu denotes fully ordained monks.

dhovāpetvā.meaning_2: having caused to wash; having had washed
dhovāpetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the absolutive form of the causative verb dhovāpeti, indicating an action completed prior to the main verb in the sentence. It denotes causing someone to wash or clean something.

sappinavanītamadhuphāṇitādīni.meaning_2: ghee, fresh butter, honey, sugar treacle, etc.; things beginning with ghee
sappinavanītamadhuphāṇitādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda-like compound listing substances, ending with ādi to indicate 'and the like'. The -īni ending shows neuter nominative/accusative plural, likely functioning as the object in a sentence discussing such items, possibly in a Vinaya or dietary context.

saṅghanavakabhikkhunā.meaning_2: by the most junior monk in the community; by the monk with less than five years' seniority
saṅghanavakabhikkhunā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the instrumental singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound saṅghanavakabhikkhu, referring to a monk who is the most junior in the monastic community, likely a newly ordained bhikkhu with minimal seniority.

laddhacīvarasāṭakā.meaning_2: having obtained a robe and cloak
laddhacīvarasāṭakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adjective, likely qualifying a masculine noun in the sentence. It describes someone who has acquired both a robe (cīvara) and an outer garment or cloak (sāṭaka), possibly in the context of monastic attire or provisions.

satasahassagghanakā.meaning_2: worth one hundred thousand (coins); valued at one hundred thousand
satasahassagghanakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ends in -akā, suggesting a feminine nominative singular or an adjective in -ā agreeing with a feminine noun in the context; combines the numeral 'sata' (hundred) with 'sahassa' (thousand) to denote 100,000, modified by 'agghanaka' for value, likely in a monetary or worth context in Vinaya or economic discussions.

āyupariyosāne.meaning_2: end of life; death; conclusion of lifespan
āyupariyosāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where āyu (life, lifespan) is qualified by pariyosāna (end, conclusion), typically denoting the termination or end of one's life, often in the sense of death or demise in Pāḷi texts.

dhammaseno.meaning_2: army of the doctrine; host of the teaching
dhammaseno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Proper name likely referring to a person or title in Buddhist context, combining 'dhamma' (doctrine) with 'sena' (army), suggesting a defender or adherent of the teaching. No sentences provided for contextual usage.

cakkavāḷasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter nominative/accusative plural form of the compound 'cakkavāḷasahassa', denoting a collection of one thousand world-systems, often used in cosmological contexts to describe the vast scope of the Buddha's influence or enlightenment.

ekandhakārāni.meaning_2: places of single darkness; solitary dark places
ekandhakārāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in neuter neuter plural form, likely describing dark, solitary places or states metaphorically as 'one darknesses'. The form ends in -āni, typical for nt pl of a-stems.

sabbacakkavāḷesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative plural form of the compound sabbacakkavāḷa, indicating location in all world systems or cosmological realms. The compound combines 'sabba' (all) with 'cakkavāḷa' (world system, lit. wheel-circle).

ārodanaparidevanaṃ.meaning_2: cry and lamentation; weeping and wailing
ārodanaparidevanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound formed from two feminine abstract nouns, both denoting types of lamentation, likely in accusative singular form in the text.

dhammokkamabhidhārayīti.meaning_2: upheld the flaming torch of the Dhamma, thus
dhammokkamabhidhārayīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi compound combining the accusative singular of 'dhammokkā' (feminine noun meaning 'flaming torch of the Dhamma') with the 3rd singular aorist 'abhidhārayi' (from abhidhārayati, 'upheld') and the quotative particle 'iti'. It likely functions adverbially or as a finite clause marker, expressing 'he upheld the flaming torch of the Dhamma, thus' in a doctrinal or narrative context.

kañcanapabbatamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Locative singular of the compound 'kañcanapabbata' (golden mountain), likely referring to a specific sacred or mythical location in Buddhist texts.

navutikoṭisahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral expressing 90 × 10,000,000,000 = 900,000,000,000, likely used in cosmological or enumerative contexts in Pāli texts to denote vast quantities.

asītikoṭisahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound numeral indicates a large quantity, likely of beings or entities in a cosmological or enumerative context, as is common in Pāli texts for describing multitudes in soteriological or descriptive passages.

ñātisaṅghaparivuto.meaning_2: surrounded by a group of relatives; accompanied by kin

The numeral koṭisatasahassa (one billion) modifies bhikkhuparivāra (monks' retinue), emphasizing a vast assembly typical in hyperbolic descriptions of Buddhist gatherings.

dibbatūriyehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound dibbatūriya, referring to celestial or divine musical instruments in a context likely describing heavenly sounds or music.

upasoṇā.meaning_2: close application; close attention; close following

navutihatthubbedhaṃ.meaning_1: ninety-cubit height; height of ninety cubits

yakkhasenāpati.meaning_2: commander of the yakkhas; general of the daemon army

anekakoṭisatasahassānaṃ.meaning_2: countless hundreds of millions; innumerable billions
anekakoṭisatasahassānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive plural form used to indicate 'of countless hundreds of millions' in enumerating vast quantities, typical in Pāli texts for hyperbolic or emphatic numeration of cosmological or karmic scales.

candavatī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a bahuvrīhi compound where 'canda' (moon) is qualified by 'vatī' (possessing, having), suggesting 'possessing the moon' or metaphorically 'moon-adorned'. Without the sentence context, the precise usage cannot be determined, but it likely functions as a descriptive feminine noun, possibly a name or epithet.

ajjunarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun in nominative singular, combining 'ajjuna' (the Arjuna tree) with 'rukkha' (tree) for emphasis or specificity. No sentences provided for further contextual meaning.

bhāvakasannipātā.meaning_2: conjunction of states; coming together of conditions
bhāvakasannipātā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound interpreting 'bhāva' as 'state or condition' (from √bhū), 'sanna' as a form of sam (intensifying 'together'), and 'nipātā' as the masculine nominative plural of nipāta meaning 'falling down' or grammatical 'particles'. In a grammatical context, it likely refers to the combination or conjunction of states/conditions and particles, possibly a technical term in Pāḷi grammar for impersonal constructions or abstract elements falling together.

mahāvanasaṇḍavāsīnaṃ.meaning_2: residents of the great forest thicket

buddhārammaṇapītiṃ.meaning_2: delight having the Buddha as its object; joy founded on the Buddha

'having the Buddha as foundation/object') modifies pīti ('delight, joy'). In Buddhist contexts, it refers to rapture or joy arising from contemplation of the Buddha.

apakkamitvā.meaning_2: having departed; having set out; having gone away
apakkamitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form apakkamitvā is the absolutive of apakkamati, which is the prefixed form of kamati 'to go'. The prefix apa- indicates motion away from, hence 'having departed'. This is analogous to the related entries pakkamitvā (with pa-) and akkamitvā (with ā-). The word in the text matches this form exactly, likely a variant spelling or sandhi-adjusted version of apakkamitvā.

sattāhaccayena.meaning_2: after the lapse (of a week); after the passing (of seven days)
sattāhaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial form functions as a temporal expression indicating the passage of a week, commonly used in Pāḷi texts to denote events occurring after seven days.

upasālo.meaning_2: lay follower (male); lay disciple; Buddhist layman
upasālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Upasālo appears to be the vocative singular form of upāsaka, used to address a male lay follower in Pāḷi texts, particularly in Vinaya contexts for addressing lay supporters of the Saṅgha.

surāmā.meaning_2: delighting in strong drink; enjoying liquor
surāmā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form surāmā appears to be a feminine nominative singular adjective derived from the prefix su- (good, thoroughly) combined with rāma (delighting in), specifically denoting pleasure in surā (strong liquor). Without provided sentences, the interpretation is based on standard Pāḷi compounds in Buddhist texts where such terms describe attachment to intoxicants.

soṇarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a descriptive compound where 'soṇa' (lit. 'dog', but here likely metaphorical for 'golden' or 'gold-colored', as in soṇakha 'golden-nail') combines with 'rukkha' (tree) to denote a tree of golden appearance or value. Without context sentences, the exact usage is inferred from common Pāḷi compounds involving soṇa in non-literal senses.

saddasālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound of 'sadda' (sound, noise) and 'sālā' (hall, auditorium), denoting a hall or room associated with sounds, likely a lecture hall or assembly place for recitations in monastic context.

jitamitto.meaning_2: conquered friend; friend who has been defeated
jitamitto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word jitamitto is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'jita' (past participle of jināti, 'conquered') modifies 'mitta' ('friend'), indicating a friend who has been conquered or subdued. In Buddhist contexts, it may refer to a former enemy turned friend through conquest or mastery, emphasizing themes of victory and reconciliation.

phaggunī.meaning_2: Phagguṇī; name of a month (Phagguṇa); second lunar month
phaggunī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Phaggunī refers to the month of Phagguṇa in the Pāḷi calendar, equivalent to March-April. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning based on standard usage in Pāḷi texts for lunar months.

mahāsoṇarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'mahā' means 'great', 'soṇa' means 'gold', and 'rukkho' means 'tree'. It likely refers to a magnificent golden tree, possibly in a metaphorical or legendary context such as in Buddhist narratives.

nāradabuddhassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nāradabuddhassa is a genitive singular of a tatpuruṣa compound nārada-buddha 'Nārada the Buddha', likely referring to the 16th previous Buddha named Nārada. The double genitive ending -assa results from sandhi in the compound's inflection. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

satasahassakappamatthake.meaning_2: at the end of one hundred thousand aeons
satasahassakappamatthake.construction: sata + sahassa + kappa + mattha + ka + e
satasahassakappamatthake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative adverbial compound used temporally to indicate 'at the conclusion of 100,000 aeons', common in Buddhist texts for describing vast cosmic periods.

padumuttarabuddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Proper name in vocative singular, used as direct address to the Buddha named Padumuttara, the fifteenth in the line of previous Buddhas; 'ultimate lotus Buddha'.

vebhārapabbate.meaning_2: on Vebhāra Mountain; on the mountain called Vebhāra
vebhārapabbate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound vebhārapabbata, referring to the mountain named Vebhāra located outside Rājagaha. The compound combines the proper name vebhāra with pabbata 'mountain', yielding 'Vebhāra Mountain'. The locative case indicates location, as in 'on Vebhāra Mountain'.

mahāraṭṭhiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective used substantively, denoting a governor of high status or importance.

haṃsavatī.meaning_2: (she) whose hair bristles; (she) whose hair stands up; (she) whose hair stands erect

It likely describes a female figure with bristling or standing hair, possibly in a context of excitement, fear, or joy, as haṃsati can also mean 'is glad' in some senses.

salalarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound noun referring to a type of tree, likely the pine or sal tree in a botanical or natural context.

The form 'sudassananagare' results from sandhi resolution of 'sudassanaṃ nagare'.

koṭisatakhīṇāsavā.meaning_2: one billion who has destroyed the effluents; one hundred crore arahants
koṭisatakhīṇāsavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where the numeral 'koṭisata' (one billion) modifies 'khīṇāsava' (arahant), likely denoting a vast number of enlightened beings in a hyperbolic sense common in Pāḷi literature for emphasizing the multitude of arahants.

asītikoṭidhanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound noun denoting a vast quantity of wealth, likely used in a context of abundance or offering, where 'koṭi' here functions as a numeral for 10 million.

mahānīparukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (bahubbīhi or tatpuruṣa) where 'mahā' qualifies 'nīparukkha' (kadamba tree), denoting a tree of the great or kadamba species. In Pāḷi literature, it often refers to a large or prominent kadamba tree in natural or soteriological contexts.

sabbalokuttamo.meaning_1: supreme over the entire world; best of all worlds
sabbalokuttamo.meaning_2: highest in the universe; supreme ruler of all worlds

catumahādīparajjaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely referring to the dominion over the four continents in Buddhist cosmology (cātuddīpa).

sakalaraṭṭhavāsino.meaning_2: inhabitants of the whole country; residents of every realm

raṭṭhuppādaṃ.meaning_2: arising of the country; appearance of the kingdom; coming into being of the realm
raṭṭhuppādaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely used in a context describing the origin or establishment of a kingdom or state.

ārāmikakiccaṃ.meaning_2: duty of a monastery worker; obligation of a monastery attendant
ārāmikakiccaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ārāmika (monastery worker) is the upapada governing kicca (duty, something to be done), indicating the duties associated with a monastery attendant. In Vinaya contexts, such terms often refer to monastic responsibilities.

mahāveḷurukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'mahā' (great) modifies 'veḷu' (bamboo), and the whole qualifies 'rukkho' (tree); likely referring to a specific or notable bamboo tree in the context of the text.

mandacchiddo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'manda' (dullness, stupidity) with 'acchidda' (unbroken, flawless), likely used metaphorically to describe a state of inherent or unmitigated foolishness. Without context, it may refer to solid dull-wittedness in a narrative or doctrinal sense.

ghanakkhandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from 'ghana' (dense, compact) and 'khandha' (mass, heap, aggregate), likely referring to a solid or dense lump or mass in context.

mahāsākhāhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of a compound adjective 'mahāsākhā' (great-branched), used to describe something like a tree, with 'hi' as the emphatic particle.

paṇṇāsahatthubbedhaṃ.meaning_2: fifty-cubit height; height of fifty cubits
paṇṇāsahatthubbedhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound indicating a measurement of height equivalent to fifty cubits, commonly used in Pāḷi texts to describe the stature or elevation of structures, beings, or objects.

maṇḍakappamhi.meaning_2: in the essence of the suitable; in the cream of the appropriate

sīhahanusabhakkhandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound referring to the 'jaw section of the assembly' or 'lion-jawed assembly portion', possibly in a metaphorical or anatomical context related to the thirty-two marks of a great man, where sīhahanu denotes the lion-like jaw, sabhā an assembly or group, and khandha a section or aggregate.

aṭṭhārasakappasatamatthake.meaning_2: at the end of one hundred and eighty aeons; after a period of one hundred and eighty aeons

koṭisatasahassadhanapariccāgena.meaning_1: by the sacrifice of a billionfold wealth
koṭisatasahassadhanapariccāgena.meaning_2: by the giving up of a trillion in riches; by the self-sacrifice of immense treasure

aṭṭhārasakappasataccayena.meaning_2: after the lapse of eighteen hundred aeons

sabbadassī.meaning_1: seeing all; perceiving all; knowing all; understanding all
sabbadassī.meaning_2: who sees all; who knows all; who perceives all; who understands all
sabbadassī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound adjective, likely used to describe a being with omniscient vision or knowledge, common in descriptions of enlightened figures in Pāḷi texts.

kakudharukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form kakudharukkho is the nominative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound kakudha-rukkha, referring to the arjuna tree (Terminalia arjuna), a common plant in Indian flora often mentioned in Pāḷi texts for its medicinal properties. aṭṭhanavuti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aṭṭhanavuti is a compound cardinal numeral formed by combining aṭṭha 'eight' with navuti 'ninety', resulting in 8 × 10 = 88. It is typically used in feminine agreement contexts, such as with feminine nouns like suttāni.

aṭṭhāsītisatasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral expressing 8 × 100 + 80 = 880, multiplied by 1000, yielding 880,000. The form is the neuter nominative or accusative plural, likely accusative in enumerative contexts.

mandāravapupphacchattaṃ.meaning_2: coral tree flower parasol; sunshade made of coral tree flowers
mandāravapupphacchattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular, likely functioning as an object in the sentence, describing a symbolic or ornamental parasol made from the flowers of the coral tree (Erythrina spp.), often associated with divine or heavenly imagery in Pāḷi literature.

campakarukkho.meaning_2: campaka tree; tree with fragrant flowers
campakarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, denoting 'the campaka tree'. The word appears in the text as 'campakarukkho', likely in a context describing a tree, such as in a natural or botanical setting in Pāḷi literature.

yojanamattaṃ.meaning_2: a measure of yojanas; distance in yojanas
yojanamattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where matta functions as a measure indicator, common in Pāḷi for expressing quantities; yojanamattaṃ likely denotes a specified or limited extent in terms of yojana units, as in 'a yojana's worth' or similar, though exact context is unavailable.

sattatikoṭiyo.meaning_2: seventy crores (700 000 000); seventy times ten million
sattatikoṭiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral formed by juxtaposing 'sattati' (seventy) and 'koṭi' (ten million), indicating a large number often used in ancient texts for vast quantities, such as in cosmology or economics. The form 'sattatikoṭiyo' is the feminine singular nominative with the i-suffix for euphony.

dibbagandhapupphehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound describing divine items, likely in a context of heavenly offerings or adornments.

rattaṅkurarukkho.meaning_2: tree of red shoots; tree with crimson sprouts
rattaṅkurarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Vocative singular of a descriptive compound likely referring to a tree (rukkha) characterized by its red or crimson shoots (ratta aṅkura), possibly evoking a flowering or budding tree in a poetic or narrative context. bimbijālotipi.meaning_2: thus even; indeed like this; also so
bimbijālotipi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a sandhi compound of the tree name 'bimbijāla' with 'iti api', functioning as an adverbial phrase emphasizing manner or addition, possibly in a list or description of locations.

tamandhakāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'ta-andhakāra', where 'ta' (pronoun 'that') modifies 'andhakāra' (darkness), functioning as the direct object in the sentence.

catunavutikappamatthake.meaning_2: ninety-four chapters in length; consisting of ninety-four sections
catunavutikappamatthake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'catunavutikappa' likely means 'ninety-four chapters' or 'ninety-four sections' (catunavuti 'ninety-four' + kappa 'chapter/section'), qualified by matthake 'at the top/end', indicating the total length or extent of the text in ninety-four chapters.

abhiññābalasampanno.meaning_2: endowed with supernormal powers; possessing higher knowledge and strength

mahājambuphalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'mahā' intensifies the type of 'jambuphala', referring to a large or superior variety of the rose-apple fruit in Pāḷi texts.

sambalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Appears to be a rare or context-specific term in Pāḷi, possibly denoting a state of preparedness or support; no sentences provided for contextual analysis.

sumitto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word 'sumitto' is a compound (samāsa) formed from 'su' (prefix meaning 'good' or 'well') and 'mitto' (vocative singular of 'mitta', meaning 'friend'). It likely appears in a vocative case addressing a friend in a positive or emphatic sense, common in Pāli texts for direct address.

kaṇikārarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a compound in vocative singular form, addressing the 'kaṇikāra tree'. The related entries confirm kaṇikāra as the tree name and rukkha as 'tree'. No sentences provided for further context.

saṭṭhihatthubbedhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound noun indicating a measurement of height as sixty cubits, likely in a descriptive context of dimensions in Pāli texts such as architecture or cosmology.

nihanitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Gerundive form used to indicate completed action prior to the main verb in the sentence.

dvānavutikappamatthake.meaning_2: at the end of ninety-two aeons
