varapāyāsassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound varapāyāsa, where 'vara' qualifies 'pāyāsa' as excellent or superior. Used possessively in context to indicate belonging or relation to this premium pudding.

suvaṇṇarajatapātiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative plural form of a feminine compound noun meaning 'golden or silver drinking bowls' or 'cups made of gold or silver'. The word combines 'suvaṇṇarajat' (gold or silver) with 'pāti' (cup, drinking bowl). The 'yo' ending is the nominative plural marker for feminine i-stems.

suvaṇṇarajatapātīhiyeva.meaning_2: just like a drinking bowl of gold or silver
suvaṇṇarajatapātīhiyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by the instrumental plural 'suvaṇṇarajatapātīhi' (drinking bowls of gold or silver) followed by the emphatic particle 'eva' (just, like). The form suggests a simile, comparing something to golden or silver drinking bowls.

ahatavatthakapilagāvidānādīhi.meaning_1: (of cloth) new; clean; unsoiled; lit. not beaten
ahatavatthakapilagāvidānādīhi.meaning_2: with new cloths, tawny cow's gifts, etc.; items for donation or offering beginning with unsoiled garments and brown cow alms
ahatavatthakapilagāvidānādīhi.family_compound: ahata vattha kapila gāvī dāna ādi
ahatavatthakapilagāvidānādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa-bahuvrīhi compound indicating 'beginning with gifts of tawny cows and new cloths', likely in a list of charitable donations or sacrificial items in Vinaya context.

purisagabbho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'purisagabbho' combines 'purisa' (man; male) with 'gabbha' (womb), likely referring to the male reproductive organ or a metaphorical male equivalent of a womb in a contextual sense, possibly in biological or symbolic usage.

itthigabbho.meaning_2: womb of a woman; female womb
itthigabbho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a compound noun referring to the womb in a female context, possibly in a medical or biological sense in the text.

paṭisandhiggahaṇakkhaṇe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative singular, referring to the critical instant at which the consciousness 'grasps' or connects to the new existence in Buddhist rebirth doctrine; the locative ending -e indicates 'at the moment of'.

sakaladasasahassī.meaning_2: consisting of ten thousand entirely; numbering ten thousand in every part
sakaladasasahassī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sakala modifies dasasahassī, emphasizing that the ten thousand are complete or in every part. The base dasasahassī is itself a compound adjective from dasa + sahassī.

bāttiṃsapubbanimittāni.meaning_2: the thirty-two precursors; the thirty-two foresigns; the thirty-two omens
bāttiṃsapubbanimittāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bāttiṃsa' (thirty-two) quantifies 'pubbanimitta' (precursors or omens), referring to the 32 minor signs or portents in Buddhist cosmology, such as those of a great man (mahāpuruṣa). The form is nominative plural neuter.

cakkavāḷasahassesu.meaning_2: in a thousand world systems; in a thousand solar systems
cakkavāḷasahassesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative plural form of the compound 'cakkavāḷasahassa', indicating location or context in a thousand world systems, often used in cosmological descriptions of Buddhist texts to denote vast multitudes of universes.

samālapiṃsu.meaning_2: they conversed together; they talked with one another
samālapiṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is 3rd plural aorist, indicating completed action of conversing or talking in a group context, derived by combining sama- (together) with ālapati (to address or converse).

bandhanagatā.meaning_2: gone to bondage; bound; attached; confined; imprisoned
bandhanagatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a feminine past participle form used in compounds, indicating a state of having gone into or become associated with 'bandhana' (bondage, attachment, or confinement). The exact nuance depends on context, likely metaphorical in Buddhist texts referring to being bound by defilements or saṃsāra.

andubandhanādīhi.meaning_1: binding with chains etc.; bondage with manacles and so on
andubandhanādīhi.meaning_2: binding with chains etc.; bondage with manacles and so on; lit. beginning with binding with chains
andubandhanādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound form where 'andubandhana' (binding with chains) is combined with 'ādi' (etc., beginning with), indicating a list starting with or including bondage with chains, typical in enumerative contexts in Pāḷi texts.

sabbanarakesu.meaning_2: in all hells; in every place of torment
sabbanarakesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'sabbanaraka' (all-hell), meaning 'in all hells'. The word functions as an interrogative pronoun in context, likely asking 'in what hell?' or 'in all hells?'.

madhurenākārena.meaning_2: with a sweet sound; with a lovely tone
madhurenākārena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a compound noun 'madhura-akāra', referring to the letter 'ā' characterized as sweet, likely in a grammatical or phonetic context emphasizing its pleasing quality.

sabbatūriyāni.meaning_2: all musical instruments; every kind of instrumental music
sabbatūriyāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective used nominally in the neuter nominative/accusative plural, likely referring to all types of musical instruments in a collective sense.

sakasakaninnādaṃ.meaning_2: the very own noise of each; the personal sound of each
sakasakaninnādaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is an accusative singular form of a compound adjective + noun, likely describing a personal or individual sound in context, such as each person's own noise or reverberation.

hatthūpagādīni.meaning_2: rings, bracelets, etc.; hand ornaments and the like
hatthūpagādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form hatthūpagādīni is neuter nominative/accusative plural of the compound hatthūpagādi, where hatthūpaga means 'suitable for the hand' (i.e., rings or bracelets), and ādi indicates 'beginning with' or 'etc.', listing a class of hand-worn items.

uppādayamāno.meaning_2: producing pride; generating conceit; causing egotism
uppādayamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form uppādayamāno is a present participle of the causative verb uppādayati ('produces, generates') combined with the suffix -māna from √man ('think'), forming a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'one who is producing (something)'. In context, it likely refers to generating pride or conceit, as in 'being one who produces pride'.

mudusītalavāto.meaning_2: with soft cool wind; having a mild gentle breeze
mudusītalavāto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective used to modify a masculine noun, likely in instrumental or locative case in context, evoking a pleasant atmospheric quality with softness, coolness, and wind.

ākāsagamanaṃ.meaning_2: going in the sky; flying; aerial movement
ākāsagamanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ākāsa (space, sky) is the upapada qualifying gamana (going), indicating movement or progression through the air or sky, often used in contexts describing supernatural abilities like those of enlightened beings.

asandamānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form asandamānā is the feminine nominative singular of the present participle, indicating something (likely a river or stream) that is not flowing or running, formed by the negative prefix a- attached to the present stem of √sand.

sañchannatalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sañchannatalo appears to be a sandhi combination of sañchanna (adj. 'covered') and talo (nt. 'surface' or 'roof'), likely meaning 'on the covered surface' or similar, though no sentences are provided for full contextual analysis.

thalajajalajādīni.meaning_2: terrestrial, aquatic, etc.; things such as land-born and water-born
thalajajalajādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound ending in ādīni, functioning as a neuter plural form indicating a class of things beginning with thalaja (terrestrial) and jalaja (aquatic), often used in enumerative contexts like the elements or beings classified by origin.

sabbapupphāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter nominative or accusative plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'sabbapuppha' meaning 'all flowers', likely in a context referring to every kind of flower or all floral elements.

khandhapadumāni.meaning_2: heaps of lotuses; piles of lotus flowers
khandhapadumāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely referring to clusters or masses of lotus flowers, possibly in a descriptive or poetic context involving abundance or natural scenery.

sākhāpadumāni.meaning_2: lotus flowers with branches; branched lotuses
sākhāpadumāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in nominative plural, likely describing lotuses that have branches or are branched in form, used in a textual context to denote a type of lotus or floral imagery.

latāpadumāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely used metaphorically for entwined or creeper-like lotuses in a poetic or descriptive context.

silātalāni.meaning_2: stone slabs; stone surfaces; stone bases
silātalāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word silātalāni is the nominative plural form of a compound noun combining 'silā' (stone) and 'tala' (flat surface or base), referring to stone slabs or flat stone surfaces, likely in an architectural or foundational context.

daṇḍapadumāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'daṇḍa' (staff or stalk) qualifies 'paduma' (lotus), referring to lotus stalks. The form 'daṇḍapadumāni' is nominative or accusative plural neuter.

olambakapadumāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form olambakapadumāni is the neuter nominative/accusative plural of the compound olambakapaduma. It combines 'olambaka' (hanging down, from ava + √lamb) and 'paduma' (lotus), likely describing lotuses that hang down, such as those on pendulous stalks. No contextual sentences are provided, so the meaning is inferred from the components.

pupphavassā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pupphavassā is the genitive singular of the tatpuruṣa compound pupphavassa, referring to a rain or downpour of flowers, a common poetic expression in Pāḷi for a shower of blossoms.

dibbatūriyāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound noun referring to divine or celestial musical instruments, likely in the context of heavenly music or sounds produced by such instruments.

vajjiṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'vajjiṃsu' appears to be a scribal error or variant for 'vajjī assu', where 'vajjī' is the adjective 'Vajjian' and 'assu' is the 3rd plural optative of 'atthi' meaning 'may they be'. Without the full sentence, this interpretation fits the provided dictionary entries.

vissaṭṭhamālāguḷo.meaning_2: one with a released garland string; one whose garland cord is loose
vissaṭṭhamālāguḷo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'vissaṭṭha' (loose, released) modifies the combined 'mālāguḷa' (garland-string), likely referring to a monk or ascetic whose ritual garland cord has been loosened or removed, possibly symbolizing renunciation. The exact context from the sentence would clarify the situational use, but no sentences are provided.

baddhamālākalāpo.meaning_2: bound garland bundle; quiver tied with a garland
baddhamālākalāpo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'baddha' modifies the combined 'mālākalāpa', likely referring to a bundle of garlands that is tied or fastened, possibly in a ritual or ornamental context; 'kalāpa' as quiver is less likely here given the floral connotation of 'mālā'.

mālāsanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'garland-eating' or 'feeding on garlands', possibly referring to a plant or creature that consumes flowers or garlands, based on the components mālā (garland) and asana (eating). Without contextual sentences, the precise usage is uncertain.

ekamālāmālinī.meaning_2: having a single garland; adorned with one wreath
ekamālāmālinī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'eka' modifies 'mālā', and 'mālā' serves as the base for the adjective 'mālinī', resulting in a feminine form in the nominative singular describing something wreathed in a single garland.

vipphurantavāḷabījanī.meaning_1: fan made of tail hair that is vibrating
vipphurantavāḷabījanī.meaning_2: vibrating fan made of tail hair; trembling whisk of animal tail
vipphurantavāḷabījanī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed by present participle 'vipphuranta' (vibrating) modifying 'vāḷabījanī' (fan made of tail hair), likely describing a whisk or fly-whisk in motion, possibly in a ritual or descriptive context.

pupphadhūmagandhaparivāsitā.meaning_2: perfumed with the scent of flower-smoke; scented with floral incense
pupphadhūmagandhaparivāsitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adjective describing something feminine (e.g., a garment or body part) that has been permeated or perfumed by the fragrant smoke from burning flowers, common in ancient perfuming practices. The structure breaks down as puppha (flower) + dhūma (smoke) + gandha (scent) + parivāsitā (perfumed, feminine nominative singular).

paramasobhaggappattā.meaning_2: endowed with supreme beauty or splendour; possessed of utmost magnificence
paramasobhaggappattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex compound adjective in instrumental singular feminine, likely describing a female figure (e.g., a goddess or queen) as having attained the highest level of beauty or glory in a narrative context; combines 'parama' (supreme) with 'sobhā' (splendour, from √sobh or √subh) intensified by 'agga' (top) and 'patta' (reached).

gahitapaṭisandhikassa.meaning_2: of one who has grasped the rebirth-linking; of one who has taken hold of the connection to the next existence
gahitapaṭisandhikassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'gahita' (past participle of gaṇhāti, 'grasped') modifies 'paṭisandhika' (adjective from paṭisandhi, 'rebirth-linking'). The form is genitive singular masculine, indicating possession or relation, likely referring to a person or entity that has mentally grasped or understood the concept of rebirth-linking in a Buddhist doctrinal context.

upaddavanivāraṇatthaṃ.meaning_2: for the sake of warding off calamities; for the purpose of preventing misfortunes
upaddavanivāraṇatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound used adverbially to indicate purpose, common in Pāli for expressing 'for the sake of'. The compound breaks down as upaddava (calamity) + nivāraṇa (warding off) + attha (purpose), yielding 'the purpose of warding off calamities'.

nuppajji.meaning_2: did not experience suffering; did not suffer
nuppajji.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nuppajji is the 3rd singular aorist of the negative verb na pajjati, combining the question particle nu with the aorist pajji from pajjati ('to suffer'). In context, it likely expresses a rhetorical question implying 'did [he] not suffer?' highlighting an instance of experienced hardship.

antokucchigataṃ.meaning_2: gone into the inner womb; situated in the innermost part of the womb
antokucchigataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in neuter accusative singular, likely describing a fetus or something that has entered the deepest part of the womb, combining 'anto' (inner/within) with 'kucchigata' (gone into the womb).

āvutapaṇḍusuttaṃ.meaning_2: thread covered with light brown (dye); pale yellow thread; thread dyed in pale color
āvutapaṇḍusuttaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a thread that is covered or dyed in a pale or light brown color, likely referring to a specific type of dyed string in a textual or ritual context. The first part āvuta functions adjectivally modifying paṇḍusutta.

vasitakucchi.meaning_2: mastery of the belly; control over the stomach
vasitakucchi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vasitā (feminine abstract noun meaning 'mastery') combines with kucchi (masculine noun meaning 'stomach, belly') to denote control or mastery over the stomach, likely in the sense of self-restraint or ascetic discipline.

cetiyagabbhasadisā.meaning_2: similar to the dome of a pagoda; like a pagoda dome
cetiyagabbhasadisā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound functions as an adjective describing something resembling the inner chamber or dome of a cetiya (stupa or pagoda). No contextual sentence provided, so meaning inferred from components.

bodhisattamātudhammatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'dhammatā' (nature, characteristic) is qualified by 'bodhisattamātu' (genitive of bodhisattamātar, mother of the Bodhisatta), indicating the inherent quality or nature pertaining to the Bodhisatta's mother. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is inferred from components.

paripuṇṇagabbhā.meaning_2: with a full womb; pregnant; with completed gestation
paripuṇṇagabbhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular feminine form used adjectivally to describe a female with a fully developed or completed womb, often implying pregnancy in Pāḷi texts.

suddhodanamahārājassa.meaning_2: of king Suddhodana, the great king; of the Buddha's father, the supreme ruler of the Sakyans
suddhodanamahārājassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular of the tatpuruṣa compound 'suddhodana-mahārāja', referring to the father of the Buddha in narrative contexts; 'suddhodana' lit. 'white rice' is a proper name, compounded with 'mahārāja' to denote his royal status.

devadahanagaraṃ.meaning_2: name of a Sakyan town; lit. town of the lake of the gods (or) town of the fire of the gods
devadahanagaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is the accusative singular form of the compound noun, used as the object in the sentence. Devadaha is a proper name of a town in the Sakyan territory, known from the suttas.

devadahanagarā.meaning_1: name of a Sakyan town; lit. town of the lake of the gods
devadahanagarā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'devadaha' (lake or fire of the gods, a Sakyan town) with 'nagara' (town), referring to the town of Devadaha in the Sakyans' territory.

kadalipuṇṇaghaṭadhajapaṭākādīhi.meaning_2: with decorative items such as banana plants, full pitchers, flags, banners, and the like
kadalipuṇṇaghaṭadhajapaṭākādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of a complex dvanda or bahuvrīhi compound ending in ādi, indicating a series of auspicious or decorative symbols used in rituals or adornments, such as in temple decorations or processions.

alaṅkārāpetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an absolutive derived from the causative verb alaṅkārāpeti (to cause to adorn), likely from alaṅkāra (ornament) + āpajjati (to apply, cause to undergo). Used to indicate prior action in a sequence, e.g., 'having adorned, [did something else]'.

suvaṇṇasivikāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound suvaṇṇasivikā, denoting 'with a golden palanquin' or 'in a golden litter', likely describing a mode of transport in a narrative context involving royalty or nobility.

amaccasahassena.meaning_2: with a thousand ministers; with a thousand councillors
amaccasahassena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound amaccasahassa, denoting accompaniment by one thousand ministers or advisors. The word appears to be a compound numeral in administrative context, likely describing a large retinue or assembly.

ukkhipāpetvā.meaning_2: causes to raise; causes to lift up; causes to elevate
ukkhipāpetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ukkhipāpetvā is the absolutive of the causative present verb ukkhipāpeti, derived from ud + √khīp (to throw or cast) with āp causative extension. It denotes the action of causing something to be lifted up, completed before the main verb in the sentence.

ubhayanagaravāsīnampi.meaning_2: even the resident of both cities; even a citizen of both towns
ubhayanagaravāsīnampi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective used substantively, with api adding emphasis ('even'), referring to someone residing in both cities, likely in a Vinaya context discussing applicability to such individuals.

lumbinīvanaṃ.meaning_1: Lumbinī grove; the grove at Lumbinī where the Buddha was born
lumbinīvanaṃ.meaning_2: Lumbinī grove; the grove at Lumbinī where the Buddha was born
lumbinīvanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'lumbinī' specifies the location of the 'vana' (grove). The form 'lumbinīvanaṃ' is the accusative singular, likely used as the object in the sentence to refer to the birthplace of the Buddha.

maṅgalasālavanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound, likely referring to a grove of sal trees considered auspicious or associated with festive/royal contexts.

cittalatāvanasadisaṃ.meaning_2: similar to the Cittalatāvana; resembling the variegated creeper wood
cittalatāvanasadisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an inflected form (accusative singular neuter) of a tatpuruṣa compound adjective meaning 'similar to the Cittalatāvana park'. The base noun cittalatāvana refers to a specific pleasure garden in Tāvatimsa Heaven, and sadisa adds the sense of resemblance.

sālavanakīḷaṃ.meaning_2: playing in the sal grove; enjoying oneself in the sal wood
sālavanakīḷaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sālavan' (sal grove) serves as the object of the present participle 'kīḷaṃ' (playing), indicating the location of the activity. The visarga in 'sālavanakīḷaṃ' results from sandhi resolution of 'sālavan + akīḷaṃ'.

kīḷitukāmatācittaṃ.meaning_2: having a mind desiring to play; with a senseless mind wanting fun
kīḷitukāmatācittaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular neuter adjective used as a bahuvrīhi compound describing something with a mind that is both 'desiring to play' (kīḷitukāma) and 'senseless' (acitta). The -ta- suffix intensifies the nominal aspect of kāma, turning it into an abstract noun qualified by citta, resulting in a complex descriptive term for a playful yet uncomprehending state of mind.

maṅgalasālamūlaṃ.meaning_2: auspicious sal tree root; base of the auspicious sal tree
maṅgalasālamūlaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter nominative/accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, where maṅgala modifies sālamūla. In Buddhist contexts, it may refer to a symbolically auspicious location, such as the base of a sal tree associated with prosperity or enlightenment events.

sālasākhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular neuter of a tatpuruṣa compound 'sālasākha' meaning 'branch of a sal tree'. Used as an adjective qualifying a neuter noun, hence nt pos.

gaṇhitukāmā.meaning_2: wishing to take; desiring to seize
gaṇhitukāmā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective formed from the infinitive gaṇhituṃ 'to take' and kāma 'desiring', used as a bahuvrīhi to describe someone who desires to take or seize something. The feminine nominative singular ending -ā indicates agreement with a feminine subject in the context.

sālasākhā.meaning_2: hall with branches; hall having branches
sālasākhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a descriptive compound referring to a hall or structure with branching elements, such as a pavilion with rafters or a metaphorical branched hall; exact context from sentences unavailable, but based on entries, it combines 'hall' and 'branch'.

suseditavettaggaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular neuter of the compound suseditavettagga, likely describing a cane sprout that has been thoroughly steamed or caused to perspire, possibly in a ritual or culinary context.

hatthapathaṃ.meaning_2: hand-path; way of the hand; manual mode
hatthapathaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a tatpuruṣa compound where 'hattha' (hand) qualifies 'patha' (path), suggesting a path or way involving the hand, possibly metaphorical for a manual or practical approach. The accusative singular ending indicates it functions as a direct object in the sentence.

athassā.grammar: pron, fem dat sg of ima
athassā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form athassā appears to be a sandhi combination of atha 'then' and assā 'to her', functioning adverbially as 'then to her' or 'and so for her' in narrative contexts, such as introducing a subsequent action directed toward a female referent.

evassā.meaning_2: only to her; just for her
evassā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi combination of the indeclinable eva ('only, just') with the feminine dative singular pronoun assā ('to her') from ima ('this'). Used to emphasize exclusivity in relation to her.

suvaṇṇajālaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from suvaṇṇa 'golden' and jāla 'net'; the accusative singular form indicates direct object usage in context.

suvaṇṇajālena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in a context likely describing a net made of or colored gold, possibly metaphorical for a beautiful or valuable entanglement.

mātukucchisambhavena.meaning_2: by birth from the mother's womb; by origin from the mother's belly
mātukucchisambhavena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound mātukucchisambhava, indicating the means or origin of birth, commonly used in Buddhist texts to describe conventional human birth from the womb.

nikkhittamaṇiratanaṃ.meaning_2: discarded jewel treasure; rejected precious gem; set aside gemstone
nikkhittamaṇiratanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines the past participle 'nikkhitta' (dropped, discarded) with 'maṇiratana' (jewel treasure), likely describing a precious gem that has been thrown down or rejected, possibly in a narrative context of loss or abandonment.

sakkāratthaṃ.meaning_2: purpose of honour; matter of respect; function of accolade
sakkāratthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sakkāratthaṃ is the accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound sakkārattha, denoting 'the purpose or matter concerning honour'. Used adverbially in compounds to indicate 'for the sake of honour'.

maṅgalasammatāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in the dative singular feminine form, used to describe something considered or agreed upon as auspicious in context.

dukūlacumbaṭakena.meaning_1: with a pad or coil of fine cloth
dukūlacumbaṭakena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound dukūlacumbaṭaka; dukūla refers to fine cloth, cumbaṭaka to a pad or coil, suggesting a cushion or bundled fine fabric. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is based on dictionary entries.

puratthimadisaṃ.meaning_2: beginning with the eastern direction; starting from the front
puratthimadisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form puratthimadisaṃ is the accusative singular of a compound puratthim-ādi, where ādi indicates 'and so on' or 'beginning with'. It likely refers to directions starting from the east (or front), common in Pāḷi texts for listing orientations.

ekaṅgaṇāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ekaṅgaṇāni is the neuter nominative/accusative plural of the compound ekaṅgaṇa, combining 'eka' (one, single) with 'aṅgaṇa' (courtyard). Without a specific sentence provided, the meaning is inferred as a group of individual or solitary courtyards.

uttarādisāti.meaning_2: beginning with the north; namely the north etc.
uttarādisāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an indeclinable adverbial phrase formed by the feminine noun uttarā (north), the feminine noun disā (direction), and the quotative particle iti, commonly used in Pāli to denote 'beginning with' or 'etc.' in lists of directions or categories.

sesarājakakudhabhaṇḍahatthāhi.meaning_2: with the remaining royal ensigns in hand
sesarājakakudhabhaṇḍahatthāhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'sesarājakakudhabhaṇḍahatta', meaning 'having the remaining royal ensigns in hand' or 'with the leftover regalia held'. It likely describes someone carrying the remnants of royal symbols, perhaps in a narrative of defeat or surrender.

anugammamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the nominative singular masculine of the present participle, indicating someone who is following or going along with something or someone. The prefix 'anu' suggests conformity or imitation in the action of going.

sattamapade.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sattapada combines 'satta' (living being, from satta 2.1) with 'pada' (word, phrase, or item, from pada 04 or 10), likely referring to a 'word for a being' or 'term denoting a creature' in grammatical or philosophical context. Without sentences, the exact usage is inferred from dictionary entries.

aggohamasmiṃ.meaning_2: I am the highest in this; I am supreme in this
aggohamasmiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi compound likely from aggo ahaṃ asmiṃ, expressing 'I am the highest in this,' common in doctrinal contexts asserting supremacy, such as in Buddhist suttas.

lokassātiādikaṃ.meaning_2: beginning with 'loka' thus, and so forth
lokassātiādikaṃ.construction: loka + ssa + ati + ādi + ka + m
lokassātiādikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as a neuter accusative singular form of the masculine adjective/noun ādika, listing 'loka' in genitive with iti ('of the world, thus') as the starting point, followed by etc.

nikkhantamattova.meaning_2: only to the extent of having departed; merely gone out
nikkhantamattova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as an adverbial phrase, likely meaning 'only to the extent of having gone out' or 'merely departed,' based on the components nikkhanta (past participle of nikkhamati, 'departed'), matta (extent or measure), and eva (only, just). Without the specific sentence context, the precise usage is inferred from dictionary meanings, possibly indicating a limited or mere departure in a narrative or doctrinal sense.

mahosadhattabhāve.meaning_2: in the state of a great foolish being; in the condition of a highly deluded creature
mahosadhattabhāve.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular of the compound 'mahosadhattabhāva', where 'osadha' likely functions as an intensive prefix or variant of 'u' (as in 'usadha') to intensify 'sadha' (mockery, folly), yielding 'mahosadha' as 'great folly'. This suggests a state of profound delusion or foolish existence, with 'attabhāva' indicating the personal or individual condition. In context, it may refer to the deluded state of beings in samsara.

nikkhantamattasseva.meaning_1: gone out only; just as something that has passed
nikkhantamattasseva.meaning_2: only that which has elapsed; merely the departed
nikkhantamattasseva.construction: nī + √kam > kham + ta + √mā + ta + ssa + eva
nikkhantamattasseva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in genitive singular with 'iva' (like). The sense is 'like (that of) only what has gone out,' often used in contexts of impermanence where things are compared to mere departed phenomena, emphasizing transience or non-substantiality.

osadhadārakotvevassa.grammar: sandhi, nt + masc + nt + ind + pron
osadhadārakotvevassa.meaning_2: in the state of being a medicinal herb and a boy only for him
osadhadārakotvevassa.family_compound: osadha dāraka ko ut + eva + assa
osadhadārakotvevassa.construction: osadha + dāraka + ko + ut + eva + assa
osadhadārakotvevassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a complex sandhi compound, likely in a locative or abstract sense ('in the state of being'), combining 'osadha' (medicinal herb) and 'dāraka' (boy) with 'ko' (what?, stem of ka) and 'ut' (in locative as -utte, state), modified by 'eva' (only) and 'assa' (genitive 'of him'). The exact parsing may depend on the full sentence context, possibly philosophical or doctrinal.

andhabadhirādīnaṃ.meaning_2: blind and deaf etc.; those who are blind, deaf, and so on
andhabadhirādīnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi-like compound in the genitive plural neuter, likely referring to categories of afflicted beings such as the blind, deaf, and others in a similar state of sensory or physical impairment, common in Buddhist contexts discussing compassion or impermanence.

sabbarogavūpasamāya.meaning_1: calming of all diseases; subsiding of every illness
sabbarogavūpasamāya.meaning_2: peace from all ailments; appeasement of every disease
sabbarogavūpasamāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the dative singular, used to indicate the purpose or object of calming, e.g., 'for the subsiding of all diseases' in a context of healing or pacification.

uppannavacanaṃ.meaning_2: expression of what has arisen; statement regarding the born or appeared
uppannavacanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'uppanna' (arisen, born) qualifies 'vacana' (word, statement), likely indicating a term or utterance concerning something that has come into being. Without the specific sentences provided, the exact contextual usage cannot be pinpointed, but it fits common Pāḷi patterns in doctrinal or grammatical discussions.

mahosadhotvevassa.meaning_2: in the great mockery only to him
mahosadhotvevassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound 'maha-sadha-utu-eva-assa' resolving to 'mahosadhotvevassa'. Likely contextually means 'only in the great season of mockery to him/it', where 'sadha' as ridicule fits a scenario of derision, 'utu' as season or time, and 'assa' as dative/genitive 'to him' or 'of him'. The exact sentence context would clarify the precise usage.

nibbattosi.meaning_2: produced (from); extracted (from); drawn (from); arisen; appeared; born, reborn
nibbattosi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nibbattosi is the 2nd person singular perfect of nibbattati, equivalent to 'you have been produced/arisen/born'. Without the sentence context, the primary sense cannot be precisely determined, but it likely relates to origin or manifestation in a doctrinal discussion.

jātakkhaṇepissa.meaning_2: even at that moment; just then
jātakkhaṇepissa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form of 'jātakhaṇe pi', where 'jātakhaṇe' is the locative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound 'jātakhaṇa' meaning 'the moment of arising/birth'. The 'pi' adds emphasis or concessive nuance, often translated as 'even' or 'just'. In context, it likely indicates immediacy of an event's occurrence.

lumbinīvane.meaning_2: grove of Lumbinī; the garden where the Buddha was born
lumbinīvane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'lumbinī + vana', meaning 'in the grove of Lumbinī'. Lumbinī is the feminine form of the place name Lumbinī, and vana means forest or grove. This refers to the famous birthplace of the Buddha.

mahābodhirukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative singular form of the compound 'mahābodhirukkha', which combines 'mahā' (great) with 'bodhirukkha' (Bodhi tree). It refers to the famous tree under which the Buddha attained enlightenment, often mentioned in Pāḷi texts in this extended form for emphasis.

gāvutappamāṇā.meaning_2: boundless as a gāvuta; immeasurable like a gāvuta (measure of length)
gāvutappamāṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form gāvutappamāṇā is the ablative singular neuter of the compound adjective gāvutappamāṇa, used in similes to denote something extending an immeasurable distance comparable to a gāvuta (a quarter yojana).

aḍḍhayojanappamāṇā.meaning_2: approximately ten kilometres; lit. measuring the length of half a yojana
aḍḍhayojanappamāṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound indicates a distance equivalent to half a yojana, which is roughly 10 km, used as an adverbial accusative in the text to specify the extent of travel or separation.

tigāvutappamāṇā.meaning_2: measuring three gāvutas but immeasurable; three gāvutas in extent yet boundless
tigāvutappamāṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (karmadhāraya) where tigāvuta specifies the conventional measure and appamāṇa indicates transcendence of that measure, likely used in a cosmological or metaphorical context to describe something vast beyond ordinary reckoning.

yojanappamāṇā.meaning_2: of the length of a yojana; measuring a yojana
yojanappamāṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used adverbially to indicate approximate distance, equivalent to 'about a yojana' where yojana denotes a traditional measure of roughly 20 km.

ubhayanagaravāsino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective used substantively in the nominative plural masculine, referring to the residents of both cities or towns.

kapilavatthunagarameva.meaning_2: right there in the city of Kapilavatthu only
kapilavatthunagarameva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi-resolved form of a compound phrase, likely from a locative construction such as 'kapilavatthunagare eva' meaning 'precisely in Kapilavatthu city'. The word in the text appears to be a scribal or variant spelling without the locative ending 'e', but contextually indicates location and emphasis on exclusivity.

bodhitale.meaning_2: at the base of the Bodhi tree; under the Bodhi tree
bodhitale.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative form of the compound bodhitala, meaning 'at the base/foot of the Bodhi tree'. It refers to the location beneath the sacred Bodhi tree where the Buddha attained enlightenment, often used in descriptions of that site.

celukkhepādīni.meaning_1: beginning with waving of garments, etc.
celukkhepādīni.meaning_2: waving of garments and the like; etc. starting with waving of garments
celukkhepādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears as a neuter plural form in a list, indicating various initial items or examples starting with the waving of garments as a sign of applause. The ādi ending denotes 'etc.' or 'and so forth', common in enumerations.

aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī.meaning_2: one who has attained the eight meditative attainments
aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective describing a person who has gained the eight jhāna attainments (samāpatti) in Buddhist meditation practice. The term combines the numeral 'eight' with 'attainment' and the agent noun 'gainer'.

kāḷadevīlo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a compound noun referring to a mythical black or dark demon in Pāḷi literature, possibly from folklore influences. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is based on component analysis: kāḷa (black) + devila (demon, from Sinhala/Pāḷi deva + ila).

divāvihāratthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of daytime meditation; for the sake of a daytime rest
divāvihāratthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the dative singular, used to express purpose, likely in a monastic context referring to a place or practice for daytime meditation or rest during the heat.

mayhampetaṃ.meaning_2: this to me; this for me
mayhampetaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi form resulting from the elision of the final nasal of mayhaṃ before the initial vowel of etaṃ; used as a possessive demonstrative phrase indicating 'this of mine' or 'this for me' in context.

suddhodanarañño.meaning_2: name of the Buddha's father; king of the Sakyans; lit. white rice
suddhodanarañño.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'suddhodanarañño' is a sandhi compound where the genitive singular 'suddhodanasya' (of Suddhodana) combines with 'rañño' (of the king), resulting in a double genitive construction emphasizing possession or relation to the king Suddhodana.

buddhalīḷaṃ.meaning_2: Buddha's sport; divine play of the Buddha; playful manifestation of the Buddha
buddhalīḷaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term buddhalīḷaṃ appears to be a neuter nominative singular form of a compound noun, likely referring to the playful or miraculous acts of the Buddha in a narrative or doctrinal context, such as in later Pāḷi literature or commentaries.

tuṭṭhāmhāti.grammar: pr 1st pl of atthi, pp of √tus
tuṭṭhāmhāti.meaning_2: we are pleased; we are satisfied; we are content
tuṭṭhāmhāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tuṭṭhāmhā is a periphrastic present construction using the past participle tuṭṭha (pleased, satisfied) with the 1st plural existential verb amhā (we are), expressing a state of being content. This is common in Pāli for stative presents derived from past participles.

vandāpetuṃ.meaning_2: to honour; to pay respect (to); to bow down (to)
vandāpetuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vandāpetuṃ appears to be a sandhi variant or scribal error for vandetuṃ, the standard infinitive of vandati, as no direct entry exists for āpe- in this context; the infinitive typically expresses purpose or intended action in sentences involving motion or obligation.

tenattabhāvena.grammar: ind, adv, instr sg of attabhāva
tenattabhāvena.meaning_2: by that state; on account of that existence; with that being; thereby in terms of personal identity
tenattabhāvena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial instrumental form of the compound 'attabhāva' (self-state or personal existence), combined with the demonstrative 'ta' (that). It functions as an adverb meaning 'by that state of being' or 'in that personal capacity', commonly used in Pāli to denote manner or reason involving one's own nature or incarnation.

vanditabbayuttako.meaning_2: one who should be honoured appropriately; one who deserves proper respect
vanditabbayuttako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'vanditabba' (potential passive participle meaning 'to be worshipped') qualifies 'yuttaka' (adjective meaning 'suitable'), indicating something or someone deserving of fitting honour.

paggahesi.meaning_2: took; grasped; held up; lifted; seized
paggahesi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This form appears to be a prefixed variant of aggahesi, with 'pa-' indicating forward or intensive action, aligning with the meanings of effort, lifting, or donation in the nominal forms of paggaha.

acchariyapuriso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound adjective 'acchariya' (wonderful) qualifying the masculine noun 'puriso' (person, man), likely referring to an extraordinary or enlightened individual in a Buddhist context.

buddhasatenapi.meaning_2: Buddha who is mindful; the Awakened One who is attentive
buddhasatenapi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where buddha qualifies sata, with api as an emphatic enclitic reinforcing the mindfulness of the Buddha. In Buddhist contexts, it often describes the Buddha's state of perfect awareness.

buddhasahassenapi.meaning_2: even with a thousand Buddhas; even a thousand Buddhas
buddhasahassenapi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form where 'buddha-sahassa-api' combines: buddha (masc nom sg) + sahassa (nt sg, 'thousand') + api (emphatic 'even'). The 'a' of sahassa elides before api, resulting in buddhasahassāpi. It functions adverbially to emphasize quantity in a concessive sense, as in 'even with a thousand Buddhas [it is not enough]'.

bodhetuṃ.meaning_2: to awaken; to cause to understand; to enlighten
bodhetuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form bodhetuṃ is the infinitive of the causative verb bodheti, derived from the root √budh 'to know, understand'. It indicates purpose or result, often translated as 'in order to awaken' in sentential contexts.

acchariyapurisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound noun, likely used as the direct object in the sentence. The first member 'acchariya' means wonderful, and 'purisa' means person or man, together denoting a person who is extraordinary or a wonder.

natthetassa.meaning_2: there is no trustworthiness for this; there is nothing reliable in him
natthetassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a sandhi compound combining 'natthi' (there is not) with 'thetassa' (genitive/dative of 'theta', meaning 'of trustworthiness' or 'to the trustworthy one'). In context, it likely negates the reliability or stability of the referent of 'this' (etassa), conveying absence of honesty or dependability.

anusocanto.meaning_1: sorrowing along; grieving following; mourning after
anusocanto.meaning_2: sorrowing (over) along; grieving (about) following; mourning (over) after
anusocanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form anusocanto combines the prefix 'anu' (indicating following or along) with the present participle of 'socati' (to grieve), suggesting a sense of grieving or mourning in a subsequent or accompanying manner. Without specific sentences, the exact contextual usage cannot be determined, but it likely describes ongoing sorrow in a narrative or poetic context.

nāḷakadārakaṃ.meaning_2: boy of the ascetic Nāḷaka; young disciple of Nāḷaka
nāḷakadārakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound where 'nāḷaka' refers to a specific ascetic (possibly from the Nāḷaka Jātaka or similar context), and 'dāraka' indicates a young boy associated with him, likely in an instrumental or accusative sense depending on sentence context.

pañcatiṃsa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pañcatiṃsa is a masculine singular cardinal number, constructed by combining pañca (five) with tiṃsā (thirty). It functions as an indeclinable numeral in Pāḷi, often used in lists or counts without further inflection.

sattāsītikoṭidhane.meaning_2: in a treasure of seven hundred eighty crores
sattāsītikoṭidhane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an inflected form (locative singular) of a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'in a treasure of seven hundred eighty koṭis (crores),' a large sum of wealth, likely in a narrative context describing riches or a king's treasury.

nibbattadārakopi.meaning_1: boy who is born (there); young boy produced (from there)
nibbattadārakopi.meaning_2: boy born in rebirth; even a child arisen there
nibbattadārakopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'nibbatta' (pp of nibbattati, 'born' or 'produced from') modifies 'dāraka' ('boy'). 'Api' is separate but included in the text, suggesting 'even the boy who is born (there)'. In Buddhist context, often relates to rebirth in a specific realm.

bodhisattābhimukhaṃ.meaning_2: towards the bodhisatta; facing the bodhisatta; in the direction of the bodhisatta
bodhisattābhimukhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial accusative form of the compound adjective bodhisattābhimukha, used to indicate direction towards the bodhisatta, a being destined for awakening.

nāḷakapaṭipadaṃ.meaning_2: path of practice of Nāḷaka; way of Nāḷaka the ascetic
nāḷakapaṭipadaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound noun 'Nāḷakapaṭipadā', where 'nāḷaka' refers to the ascetic Nāḷaka, and 'paṭipadā' means the path of practice. The compound likely denotes the specific method or path associated with Nāḷaka's teachings or practice, as seen in Pāḷi texts like the Nāḷakapāṭipadā Sutta.

catujjātikagandhehi.meaning_2: with perfumes of four types; with scents of four kinds
catujjātikagandhehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound describing perfumes categorized into four types or classes, likely referring to varieties of scents in a ritual or descriptive context.

lājāpañcamakāni.meaning_2: grains having the fifth component as fried grain; mixture with fried grain as the fifth ingredient
lājāpañcamakāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form lājāpañcamakāni is the neuter nominative/accusative plural of the tatpuruṣa compound lājāpañcamaka, where pañcamaka (derived from pañcama 'fifth') indicates something having a fifth component, here specified as lāja 'fried grain'. This likely refers to a specific mixture or preparation in a ritual or dietary context, with ā possibly indicating a connective or extended form.

asambhinnapāyāsaṃ.meaning_2: unchewed milk rice pudding; pudding not pulverized
asambhinnapāyāsaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound, used as direct object. The first member asambhinna functions adjectivally, modifying pāyāsa to indicate the pudding is unchewed or unground.

aṭṭhasatabrāhmaṇe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely refers to 108 Brahmins, a common symbolic number in Indian traditions; the form is locative singular, indicating 'among/amongst 108 Brahmins' in context.

pariggahāpesuṃ.meaning_2: caused to take possession; caused to acquire; caused to appropriate
pariggahāpesuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pariggahāpesuṃ is 3rd plural aorist of the causative pariggahāpeti, indicating a completed action of causing possession or acquisition in the past. The base pariggaha relates to 'grasping all around' from √gah with prefix pari, and the āpaya causative adds the sense of 'causing to take'.

chaḷaṅgavā.meaning_2: having six qualities; sixfold in aspect
chaḷaṅgavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound chaḷaṅgava, formed from numeral 'chaḷ' (six) and 'aṅgavant' (having qualities/aspects), likely referring to something possessing six characteristics or parts in a Pāli textual context.

viyākariṃsūti.meaning_2: like a birth that was done; as if performing a delivery
viyākariṃsūti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an adverbial phrase formed by sandhi, combining 'viya' (like), 'akariṃ' (I did, aorist 1st sg of karoti), and 'sūti' (birth) with 'iti' (thus), possibly functioning as a quotative or simile in a narrative context, such as 'like I did a birth, thus' or 'as if performing a delivery.' The exact sentence context is needed for precise interpretation.

lakkhaṇapariggāhakā.meaning_2: one who fully grasps characteristics; one who completely comprehends qualities
lakkhaṇapariggāhakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from 'lakkhaṇa' (characteristic, quality) and 'pariggāhaka' (one who grasps or comprehends), indicating a person skilled in understanding or interpreting characteristics. The feminine nominative singular ending '-ā' suggests agreement with a feminine subject in the original context.

paṭisandhiggahaṇadivase.meaning_2: on the day of grasping the rebirth-linking; on the day of taking the connection to the next existence
paṭisandhiggahaṇadivase.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the locative case, referring to the day when the consciousness links to the next existence in Buddhist rebirth doctrine. The form paṭisandhiggahaṇadivase is the locative singular of the neuter compound paṭisandhiggahaṇadivasa.

ajjhāvasamāno.meaning_2: living (in); inhabiting; staying (in); is settled (in); dwells (in); lit. living over
ajjhāvasamāno.construction: adhi > adhy > ajjh + ā + vasa + māna
ajjhāvasamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ajjhāvasamāno is the nominative masculine singular of the present participle, indicating someone who is currently dwelling or settled in a place. Without the specific sentence provided, the general sense of inhabiting or residing is assumed based on the dictionary entries.

pabbajamāno.meaning_2: ordaining; renouncing (the household life); lit. going forth
pabbajamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pabbajamāno is the nominative singular masculine of the present participle, indicating someone who is going forth or ordaining as a monastic. The -māno ending is the standard nominative masculine for a-stem participles in Pāli.

cakkavattirañño.meaning_2: of the wheel-turning monarch; of the universal king
cakkavattirañño.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'cakkavattī' (nom.sg. cakkavattī) combines with 'rañño' (gen.sg. of rāja), resulting in the form cakkavattirañño. The meaning is 'of the wheel-turning king,' a title for a righteous universal sovereign in Buddhist cosmology.

sirivibhavaṃ.meaning_2: loss of fortune; decline of glory
sirivibhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sirivibhavaṃ is the accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound sirivibhava, combining siri (fortune, glory) with vibhava (power, but here denoting loss or decline in the sense of annihilation or regress). Used as direct object in the sentence, indicating the decline or loss of fortune.

sabbadaharo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a collective or distributive expression, meaning 'every young boy' or 'all the youths,' likely referring to a group of young monks or novices in a monastic context.

varalakkhaṇanipphattiṃ.meaning_2: accomplishment of excellent auspicious marks; consummation of prominent fine characteristics
varalakkhaṇanipphattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an accusative singular form of a compound noun, likely used in a context describing the successful realization or attainment of superior bodily marks, common in descriptions of the Buddha or noble beings in Pāli literature.

ṭhānakāraṇaṃ.meaning_2: place and cause; position and reason
ṭhānakāraṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound combining 'ṭhāna' (place, position, reason) and 'kāraṇa' (cause, reason), likely denoting 'place and cause' or 'position and reason' in a contextual sense, such as grounds for something or situational causation.

ekantenesa.grammar: ind, adv, comp, instr sg of ekanta
ekantenesa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word ekantena is the instrumental singular adverbial form of the adjective ekanta, used to emphasize certainty or exclusivity in context. Without specific sentences provided, the meaning is derived from dictionary entries, likely indicating an adverbial use in a declarative or emphatic sense.

ekaṃsabyākaraṇaṃ.meaning_2: definite explanation; categorical declaration; assured statement
ekaṃsabyākaraṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'ekaṃsa' (definite, sure) with 'byākaraṇa' (explanation, declaration), indicating an explanation given with certainty or without doubt. In Pāḷi texts, such terms often appear in contexts of doctrinal exposition or authoritative pronouncements.

pacchimabhavikasatto.meaning_2: being in the last existence; creature in the final birth
pacchimabhavikasatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pacchimabhavika' (adj. 'in the last existence') qualifies 'satta' (masc. n. 'being, creature'), referring to a sentient being in its final existence before enlightenment or liberation.

atthasiddhikarattā.meaning_1: because of the role of establishing meaning
atthasiddhikarattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an instrumental feminine form of a compound noun 'atthasiddhikaratā', derived from 'atthasiddhi' (establishment of meaning) and 'karatā' (act of doing/making). The instrumental case indicates 'because of' or 'on account of' this establishment.

nāmamakaṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a compound aorist from nāma 'name' and √kar 'to do/make', meaning 'they named'. The irregularity in the base formation is analogous to the simple verb akaṃsu.

koṇḍaññamāṇavova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a sandhi-affected vocative singular of a compound noun koṇḍaññamāṇava ('Koṇḍañña the young man'), followed by iva ('like'). The -o ending suggests vocative case, common in similes or addresses in Pāli. Likely refers to the monk Koṇḍañña in his youth, used in a comparative sense.

vuḍḍhimanvāya.meaning_2: experiencing increase; undergoing prosperity; due to development
vuḍḍhimanvāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vuḍḍhimanvāya combines the accusative of the abstract noun vuḍḍhi ('increase') with the gerund anvāya of anveti, functioning as a postposition expressing accompaniment or reason, e.g., 'due to increase' or 'experiencing prosperity'. Without context, it likely denotes causation or means related to growth or elevation.

siddhatthakumāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to Siddhattha Gotama as a young prince before his enlightenment; the compound combines 'siddhattha' (accomplished in purpose) with 'kumāra' (prince).

ekacchandā.meaning_2: with one desire; with a single intention
ekacchandā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by eka (adj, 'one; single') and chanda (masc, 'desire; intention'), likely in instrumental singular to indicate 'with one desire' in a context of motivation or consent.

koṇḍaññabrāhmaṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely referring to a specific person named Koṇḍañña who is a Brāhmaṇa, possibly distinct from the famous monk Aññā Koṇḍañña.

pañcavaggiyattherā.meaning_2: the elders of the group of five
pañcavaggiyattherā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to the five bhikkhus (Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Assaji, Vakkali, and Rādha) who were early disciples of the Buddha, often mentioned in the Vinaya and Suttas as a group.

katarañcāti.meaning_2: which of the two...and so?; which...thus?
katarañcāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial phrase formed by combining the interrogative adjective 'katara' (which of two), the conjunction 'ca' (and), the enclitic 'ñ' (short for 'api', also), and 'iti' (thus). It functions to quote or delimit an interrogative expression like 'which of the two also?', often used in grammatical or doctrinal contexts to specify alternatives in a quoted manner.

dvisahassadīpaparivārānaṃ.meaning_2: of those with entourages of two thousand islands; of those surrounded by two thousand island retinues
dvisahassadīpaparivārānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in genitive plural, likely referring to beings or entities (e.g., deities or kings) each accompanied by a retinue associated with two thousand islands or continents, common in Buddhist cosmology for describing realms or followers.

chattiṃsayojanaparimaṇḍalāya.meaning_2: having a circumference of thirty-six yojanas
chattiṃsayojanaparimaṇḍalāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a compound adjective describing something with a circular extent of 36 yojanas (approximately 504 kilometers). The term parimaṇḍalā in this context specifically indicates measurement in circumference.

passitukāmoti.meaning_2: wishing to see; wanting to see; would be delighted to see
passitukāmoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound formed from the infinitive passituṃ 'to see', the adjective kāma 'wishing (to)', and the quotative particle iti 'thus', functioning as an indeclinable expression indicating desire or intention to see. It likely appears in contexts expressing perceptual or observational intent.

catuppakārānaṃ.meaning_2: of four kinds; of four types; of four manners
catuppakārānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form catuppakārānaṃ appears to be a sandhi compound where 'catu' (four) combines with 'appakāra' (deformed, ugly), but in context, it likely functions as 'of four kinds' or 'of four types', possibly a scribal error or variant for catuppakārānaṃ (from pakāra, manner). The genitive plural indicates possession or relation to four such categories, common in Pāḷi texts describing classifications.

āgamananivāraṇatthaṃ.meaning_2: for the purpose of preventing arrival; for the sake of obstructing coming
āgamananivāraṇatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound functioning adverbially to indicate purpose, commonly used in Pāḷi to express 'for the sake of' combined with the preceding elements. The compound breaks down as āgamana (arrival) + nivāraṇa (preventing) + attha (purpose), yielding the sense of intent to block or ward off arrivals, often in monastic or legal contexts like the Vinaya.

maṅgalaṭṭhāne.meaning_2: auspicious place; place of blessing; site of prosperity or ceremony
maṅgalaṭṭhāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of the compound maṅgalaṭṭhāna, indicating 'in an auspicious place'. The form shows sandhi where maṅgala + aṭṭhāna becomes maṅgalaṭṭhāna before the locative ending -e.

ñātikulasahassesu.meaning_2: in a thousand families; among a thousand households
ñātikulasahassesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound ñātikulasahassa, indicating 'in/among a thousand families'. The base compound ñātikula (family, household) is combined with sahassa (thousand) to denote a large number of family units, likely in a context of abundance or multitude.

khattiyasamaṇeheva.meaning_2: only in the case of noble ascetics; solely among noble monks
khattiyasamaṇeheva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form of 'khattiya-samaṇe eva', meaning 'only in a noble ascetic' or 'only among noble monks'. The locative 'samaṇe' (in samaṇa) combined with 'khattiya' (as adjective) and emphatic 'eva'. Likely used in a context contrasting or emphasizing noble ascetics exclusively.

purakkhataparivārito.meaning_2: surrounded by what is honoured; enveloped in esteem; preceded and encircled
purakkhataparivārito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'purakkhata' (honoured, esteemed, lit. made in front) with 'parivārita' (surrounded, enveloped), suggesting something encircled by or immersed in honour or precedence. Without contextual sentences, the precise nuance (e.g., physical surrounding vs. metaphorical) is ambiguous, but it likely conveys being wrapped in veneration or priority.

uttamarūpasampannā.meaning_2: endowed with the finest figure; supreme in beauty; possessing excellent form
uttamarūpasampannā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the feminine nominative singular form of the compound adjective uttamarūpasampanna, describing a woman or female figure with supreme physical beauty or form. The prefix uttama- elevates rūpa to its highest degree, combined with sampanna indicating endowment or fulfillment.

vigatasabbadosā.meaning_2: free from all faults; devoid of every defect; without any error
vigatasabbadosā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in the feminine instrumental singular, likely modifying a feminine noun such as 'citta' (mind) or 'sati' (mindfulness) in a context emphasizing a state free from all mental defilements or faults, common in ethical or meditative descriptions.

sirisobhaggena.meaning_2: by the highest glory; by supreme fortune and prosperity
sirisobhaggena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound sirīsobhagga 'highest glory/fortune', used adverbially to indicate the means or accompaniment of an action, likely in a context praising or describing supreme auspiciousness or divine favor.

dāsakammakarādayo.meaning_2: slaves and workers and so forth; servants, labourers, and the like
dāsakammakarādayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dāsakammakarādayo is the nominative plural of the compound dāsakammakarādī, where -ādayo is an irregular extension of the standard -ādīyo used for 'etc.' in lists, indicating a series beginning with slaves and workers.

ahatavatthanivatthā.meaning_2: clothed in new clean unsoiled cloth; dressed in fresh garments
ahatavatthanivatthā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a feminine nominative singular past participle, likely describing a female subject (e.g., a woman or goddess) who is wearing garments made of new, clean cloth. The compound ahatavattha specifies the type of clothing as unsoiled or fresh.

gandhamālādipaṭimaṇḍitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (karmadhāraya) where paṭimaṇḍitā modifies the subject, indicating adornment starting with gandhamālā (perfumes and garlands) and including other items. The ādi element introduces the sense of 'etc.' or 'beginning with'.

naṅgalasahassaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sahassa' functions as an adjective meaning 'numbering one thousand', modifying 'naṅgala' (plough). The form is accusative singular, likely functioning as the object of a verb in the missing sentence context.

ekenūnaaṭṭhasatanaṅgalāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound indicating a quantity of ploughs that is one less than 108, hence 107. The form is neuter nominative plural, likely referring to a collective or set of ploughs in the context.

balibaddarasmiyottehi.meaning_1: by the rope or reins tied to the ox's yoke
balibaddarasmiyottehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound: balibadda ('ox-yoke') + rasmi ('reins') + yotta ('yoke-tie'), in instrumental plural form. It likely refers to the harness components connecting the ox to a vehicle or plough, used in a context describing yoking or binding animals.

rajataparikkhatāni.meaning_2: endowed with silver; adorned with silver
rajataparikkhatāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form rajataparikkhatāni is the neuter nominative/accusative plural of a compound adjective, where rajata (silver) modifies parikkhata (equipped with, adorned with), indicating things equipped or adorned with silver. The long ā in -tā is a taddhita suffix forming an abstract or adjectival noun from the past participle.

ālambananaṅgalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ālambana (support) modifies naṅgala (plough), likely referring to a plough that has a support or prop mechanism. The form ālambanaṅgalaṃ is accusative singular neuter.

rattasuvaṇṇaparikkhataṃ.meaning_2: adorned with red gold; equipped with red gold
rattasuvaṇṇaparikkhataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something (likely neuter, such as a shrine or object) that is adorned or equipped with red gold, based on the primary sense of parikkhata as a past participle of parikkharoti meaning 'adorned (with)'.

siṅgarasmipatodāpi.meaning_1: adornment-rein-whip; whip for guiding a vain or ornament-loving horse
siṅgarasmipatodāpi.meaning_2: whip of the reins of adornment; goad for a horse fond of finery
siṅgarasmipatodāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely describes a whip or goad used with reins to control a horse characterized by siṅga (foppery or love of finery), suggesting a metaphorical or literal tool for guiding something vain or decorative. Api is not part of the core compound but may modify the entire phrase in context, adding emphasis like 'even' or 'indeed'.

suvaṇṇaparikkhatāva.meaning_2: as if adorned with gold; just like golden-equipped
suvaṇṇaparikkhatāva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi combination of suvaṇṇaparikkhatā (feminine noun 'golden adornment' or past participle 'adorned with gold') and -iva ('like; as'), with eva likely absorbed or variant in context. Used adverbially to describe something resembling gold-adorned, common in descriptive similes for beauty or splendor in Pāli literature.

jamburukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun in nominative singular, combining 'jambu' (rose-apple tree) and 'rukkha' (tree), referring to the rose-apple tree. No sentences provided for further contextual meaning.

bahalapalāso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely describes foliage or a tree with thick or dense leaves, combining 'bahala' (thick, dense) and 'palāsa' (leaf, foliage, or the palāsa tree known for its leaves).

paññapāpetvā.meaning_2: having caused to attain wisdom; having produced understanding
paññapāpetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound absolutive where 'paññā' (wisdom) is the object of the causative verb 'pāpeti' (to cause to reach), indicating an action of bringing about or causing the attainment of wisdom or insight, common in Buddhist contexts for teaching or realization.

suvaṇṇatārakakhacitaṃ.meaning_2: studded with golden stars; inlaid with golden stars
suvaṇṇatārakakhacitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound functioning as an adjective agreeing with an implied neuter noun, likely 'vihāraṃ' or similar in context, portraying something adorned with golden stars, evoking a luxurious or celestial appearance.

naṅgalakaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: place of making a plough; place for plough-making
naṅgalakaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in accusative singular neuter, functioning adverbially to indicate possibility ('in the case of making a plough'). The form shows assimilation of n + k to ṅg and ṭṭh from sandhi.

suvaṇṇanaṅgalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where suvaṇṇa (golden) modifies naṅgala (plough), resulting in an accusative singular form, likely referring to a plough made of or colored like gold in a metaphorical or descriptive sense.

ekenūnaṭṭhasatarajatanaṅgalāni.meaning_2: ploughs (made of) one hundred and eight silver (pieces) short of one; ploughs short of one from one hundred and eight silver ones
ekenūnaṭṭhasatarajatanaṅgalāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form -āni indicates neuter plural nominative or accusative of a compound noun. aṭṭhasata is interpreted as 108 (one hundred and eight) based on the cardinal number entry, with rajata as silver (coins or material), and naṅgala as ploughs. The ekenūna 'one less than' modifies the numeral, suggesting 107 silver ploughs or ploughs valued at 107 silver units.

sesanaṅgalāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter plural nominative or accusative, referring to ploughs that are left over or remaining, likely in the context of agricultural or monastic implements.

mahāsampatti.meaning_1: great prosperity; great welfare; great success
mahāsampatti.meaning_2: great prosperity; great welfare; great good fortune; great achievement
mahāsampatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed by the adjective 'mahā' (great) qualifying the abstract noun 'sampatti' (prosperity, success); used to denote a state of exceptional or abundant prosperity or attainment.

antosāṇito.meaning_2: from within the hemp cloth; from inside the curtain
antosāṇito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form antosāṇito is the ablative singular of the compound anto + sāṇi, indicating origin or separation from inside something made of hemp, such as a cloth or screen. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

khajjabhojjantare.meaning_2: in the interval between hard and soft food; in the variety of foods
khajjabhojjantare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a locative singular of the compound khajjabhojjantara, meaning 'in the space between' or 'among the types of' hard and soft foods, using 'tara' in the sense of interval or kind. The double 'j' likely results from sandhi in the compound khajja + bhojja.

sesarukkhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'sesa' (remainder) modifies 'rukkha' (tree), likely in the genitive plural form based on the -ānaṃ ending, indicating possession or relation to the remaining trees in context.

jamburukkhassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word jamburukkhassa is the genitive singular of jamburukkha, a compound noun meaning 'of the rose-apple tree'. It combines jambu (rose-apple tree) with rukkha (tree), referring to Syzygium jambos. Assa is the genitive ending for masculine a-stems.

vegenāgantvā.meaning_2: having come quickly; having arrived hastily
vegenāgantvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form combining the adverb 'vegena' (quickly, with force or urgency) and the absolutive 'āgantvā' (having come). It functions as an adverbial phrase indicating manner of arrival, likely meaning 'having come quickly' or 'having arrived in haste'. The sandhi resolution is vegena + āgantvā > vegenāgantvā.

navabhūmakaṃ.meaning_2: new to the region; from a new area
navabhūmakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a compound adjective 'nava' (new) + 'bhūmaka' (of the region), used in instrumental case singular neuter or accusative case singular masculine, possibly referring to a newcomer from a new or foreign area in a monastic or narrative context.

pañcabhūmakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pañcabhūmakaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the adjective pañcabhūmaka, likely describing a five-storied building or structure in context; based on bhūmaka 2 meaning 'having floors; with stories; -levelled'.

cattālīsasahassā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in numeral expressions, e.g., 'with forty thousand'; the compound combines the cardinal 'forty' with 'thousand' to denote the quantity 40,000.

alaṅkatanāṭakaparivuto.meaning_2: surrounded by decorated plays; accompanied by adorned theatrical performances
alaṅkatanāṭakaparivuto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where alaṅkata ('decorated') modifies nāṭaka ('play'), and the whole phrase is the object of parivuta ('surrounded by'). It likely describes someone accompanied by or involved with adorned theatrical or dramatic activities.

mahāsampattiṃ.meaning_1: great prosperity; great welfare; great success
mahāsampattiṃ.meaning_2: great prosperity; great welfare; great good fortune; great achievement
mahāsampattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective used as a feminine noun, combining 'mahā' (great) with 'sampatti' (prosperity), likely in accusative singular form in the original text.

utuvārena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A compound noun denoting a specific time or season, combining 'utu' (season) with 'vāra' (turn, time), likely referring to a particular period in the context of the text.

asikkhitvā.meaning_2: without having learnt; without having trained oneself; without having practised
asikkhitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The prefix 'a-' negates the action of learning or training, indicating absence of the activity.

pattakāle.meaning_2: at the right time; at the suitable time
pattakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative adverbial form from the compound pattakāla ('suitable time'), functioning as an indeclinable adverb meaning 'at the right time'. It combines patta (pp of pāpuṇāti, 'reached; suitable') and kāla ('time'). The locative ending -e indicates 'at the time of'.

sikkhanakiccaṃ.meaning_2: duty of training; obligation of learning
sikkhanakiccaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sikkhana' (training) qualifies 'kicca' (duty). The accusative singular ending '-ṃ' indicates its case in the original text, but the lemma retains the full form as a compound.

sippadassanatthaṃ.meaning_2: for the sake of seeing a skill; for the purpose of demonstrating a craft
